FlowCloud

The content of the emails in the November 2019 campaigns impersonated the American Society of Civil Engineers and masqueraded as the legitimate domain asce[.]org.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The structure of this email is very similar to the LookBack delivery emails constructed to impersonate the NCEES and Global Energy Certification in July 2019.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Examples of the emails are included in Figure 3 and Figure 4.

Figure 3 ASCE-themed phishing email delivering FlowCloud malware November 2019

Figure 4 NCEES-themed phishing email delivering LookBack malware July 2019
Exploitation - Installation Macros
As noted above, after an extended period of using PE attachments to deliver FlowCloud in campaigns, the threat actors behind FlowCloud switched to using Microsoft Word documents with malicious macros at the beginning of November 2019.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The Word document attachments and macros delivering FlowCloud had key similarities with the Word document attachments and macros we identified that delivered LookBack in July and August 2019.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Identical to the methodology used with LookBack, the FlowCloud macro used privacy enhanced mail (“.pem”)  files which were subsequently renamed to the text file “pense1.txt”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This file is next saved as a portable executable file named “gup.exe” and executed using a version of the certutil.exe tool named “Temptcm.tmp”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: For comparison, Figure 5 November 2019 macro used to install FlowCloud malware shows the macro used to install FlowCloud while Figure 6 August 2019 macro used to install LookBack malware shows the macro used to install LookBack.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Figure 5 November 2019 macro used to install FlowCloud malware

Figure 6 August 2019 macro used to install LookBack malware
The “Exploitation” section in our blog  LookBack Malware Targets the United States Utilities Sector with Phishing Attacks Impersonating Engineering Licensing Boards has a more in-depth explanation of this method used by LookBack.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: FlowCloud uses this same method exactly including identical macro concatenation code.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While we found the ultimate execution method for both the LookBack Gup proxy tool and FlowCloud malware were the same across both macro versions, we found that the FlowCloud macro introduced a new method for the delivery of the malware.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The earlier LookBack versions of the macro included the payload in numerous privacy enhanced email (“.pem”) files that were dropped when the attachment file is executed by the user.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The FlowCloud version of the macro utilized a previously unobserved macro section to download the payload from a DropBox URL.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Once the payload was downloaded, a FlowCloud malware PE in the form of a .pem file was saved as the variable “Pense1.txt”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 7 FlowCloud Malware Macro delivery code shows the FlowCloud macro with the delivery section in question called out.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Figure 7 FlowCloud Malware Macro delivery code
The FlowCloud macro also contained a strange try… catch statement which initially attempts to download the FlowCloud payload from the DropBox URL as part of the try statement.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: However, if it was unable to retrieve the payload from that resource, a catch statement which was nearly identical to the try statement attempted to retrieve a malware resource from the URL http://ffca.caibi379[.]com/rwjh/qtinfo.txt”.”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 8 FlowCloud Malware Catch statement macro code shows the catch statement in question.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Figure 8 FlowCloud Malware Catch statement macro code
This try…catch sequence is significant because the URL in the catch statement and malware resource was previously mentioned in a May 2019 blog by enSilo entitled “Uncovering New Activity by APT10”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The blog claims that this URL delivered a modified Quasar RAT payload which included the addition of SharpSploit, an opensource post-exploitation tool.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: When analyzed on the same date of FlowCloud campaign delivery this URL and resource was unavailable, while the DropBox URL successfully delivered the FlowCloud .pem file.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While Proofpoint has not independently verified these attribution claims made by other researchers regarding the referenced Quasar RAT sample, the use of this URL represents a previously undisclosed overlap with publicly reported indicators of compromise attributed to TA429 (APT10).
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While on the surface this domain may imply links to TA429 (APT10), we have identified several aberrations regarding the domain registration information and inactive nature of the URL and will discuss them at length at length later in this blog.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
FlowCloud Malware
Our analysis of the FlowCloud malware determined that it is a multi-stage payload comprised of a large code base written in C++.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The code demonstrates a level of complexity including numerous components, extensive object-oriented programming, and use of legitimate and imitation QQ files for initial and later stage execution.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We found further imitation of QQ components in several modules used throughout FlowCloud execution.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The malware name “FlowCloud” was taken from distinctive PDB paths observed in numerous malware components.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: These values have been included in the IOCs section at the end of this blog.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: FlowCloud malware is capable of RAT functionalities based on its available commands including accessing the clipboard, installed applications, keyboard, mouse, screen, files, services, and processes with the ability to exfiltrate information via command and control.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Additionally, the malware variants analyzed have several distinct characteristics that indicate the malware may have been active in the threat landscape since at least July 2016.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In addition to components built to target updated Windows versions, FlowCloud samples have dropped a 32-bit module that was only compatible with Windows versions 6 (Windows Vista) and below.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The dated nature of this binary coupled with the extensible nature of the malware code suggests that the FlowCloud code base has been under development for numerous years.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Public reports around FlowCloud malware components and related installation directory paths suggest that versions of this malware may have been observed in the wild as early as July 2016.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Additionally, development of this malware around legitimate QQ files and the identification of malware samples uploaded to VirusTotal from Japan in December 2018 and earlier this year from Taiwan indicate that the malware may have been active for some time in Asia prior to its appearance targeting the US utilities sector.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 9 Flowchart of FlowCloud Loader Functionality below outlines FlowCloud’s loader functionality.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 9 Flowchart of FlowCloud Loader Functionality
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The malware begins with the execution of Gup.exe by the malicious macro which in turn executes the file EhStorAuthn.exe.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: EhStorAuthn.exe extracts the subsequent payload file components and installs them to the directory C:\Windows\Media\SystemPCAXD\ado\fc.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This file also sets registry key values that store the keylogger drivers and the malware configuration as the value “KEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\Setup\PrintResponsor\<2-4>”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: EhStorAuthn.exe is a legitimate portable executable file used by QQ with the initial name QQSetupEx.exe.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This file is used to load the file dlcore.dll as part of its natural downloader routine.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Dlcore.dll is a DLL crafted by the threat actors that functions as a shellcode injector pulling the shellcode from a file named rebare.dat.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This file imitates a legitimate QQ component.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: When the shellcode within rebare.dat is executed it in turn executes a RAT installer file named rescure.dat.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Rescure.dat is an XOR encrypted DLL file that installs the RAT based application responsor.dat which installs the keylogger driver and manages the RAT functionality.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Responsor.dat unpacks several modules (rescure86.dat or rescure64.dat) to the registry %TEMP%\{0d47c9bc-7b04-4d81-9ad8-b2e00681de8e}" and installs the unpacked file as a service named “FSFilter Activity Monitor” or “FltMgr”.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Finally, Responsor.dat starts the RAT when the rescure.dat function “startModule” is called.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Several legitimate Microsoft Windows files were also used by the malware for thread injection.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: EhStorAuthn_shadow.exe (hhw.exe) a Microsoft HTML Help Workshop file was used as a placeholder for thread injection.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Hha.dll is a component of Microsoft HTML Help Workshop and is required to run EhStorAuthn_shadow.exe.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The malware stores its configuration in the registry alongside drivers utilized by the malware’s keylogger components.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Several additional distinct registry keys are generated which indicate the malware’s current execution stage on the host.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Some of these keys are included in the table below.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:

source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
FlowCloud Configuration
The FlowCloud loader component EhStorAuthn.exe stores the malware configuration in the registry early in the installation chain and is represented in the table above.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The Registry data is composed of multiple encrypted headers (using XORs and RORs) and data is encrypted using a modified (or broken) AES algorithm.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The plaintext data is compressed with ZLIB and serialized using Google’s Protocol Buffers.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
￼Figure 10 shows an example of a configuration as displayed by FlowCloud’s debug logging:

Figure 10 Example of a configuration as displayed by debug logging
Command and Control
FlowCloud malware handles configuration updates, file exfiltration, and commands as independent threads utilizing a custom binary C2 protocol.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We identified these independent threads as part of an extensive command handling functionality with distinct command managers existing for each command.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The sample we analyzed utilized port 55555 for file exfiltration and port 55556 for all other data.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We identified FlowCloud communication with the IP 188.131.233[.]27.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The requests and responses are composed of multiple encrypted headers (using XORs and RORs) and TEA encrypted data using a key generation scheme involving a hardcoded string of random characters and MD5 hashing.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The plaintext data is compressed using ZLIB and serialized using Google’s Protocol Buffers.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
An example parsing of an initial beacon is demonstrated in Figure 11 Example of FlowCloud parsing an initial C2 beacon:

Figure 11 Example of FlowCloud parsing an initial C2 beacon
Comparing Public TA429 (APT10) Indicators with TA410 Campaigns
Publications by FireEye and EnSilo regarding TA429 (APT10) campaigns contain indicators that later appeared in TA410 campaigns.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In our retrospective analysis of that research, we determined that TA429 (APT10) used phishing macros that were later seen being used by LookBack and FlowCloud malware.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Additionally, we identified the Quasar RAT delivery URL hxxp://ffca.caibi379[.]com/rwjh/qtinfo.txt used by FlowCloud macros in November, which was published in the enSilo report prior to observable weaponization for TA410 campaigns.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Interestingly, the compilation date of several LookBack malware modules used in July 2019 were September 14, 2018.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This includes the SodomMain and SodomNormal modules covered in previous Proofpoint blogs on LookBack malware.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: That date is just one day after FireEye released their initial analysis of similar TA429 (APT10) macros utilized in Japan on September 13, 2018.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While LookBack malware samples were not observed in the wild until June 2019, this September 2018 compilation date demonstrates a large lag time between compilation and delivery.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This possibly suggests manipulation of compilation times by threat actors but has not been conclusively determined.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The first identified server installation by TA410 on actor-controlled infrastructure occurred in December 2018.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Most of the domain registration (weaponization) for LookBack and FlowCloud campaigns began in May and June 2019 respectively.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: These events were after FireEye’s initial publication in September 2018.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Additionally, enSilo’s publication on potentially TA429 (APT10) related Quasar RAT samples was published on May 24, 2019.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: It was not until the second week of November 2019 when the inactive URL was incorporated into a phishing macro as part of a FlowCloud campaign targeting US utilities.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: WHOIS records and passive DNS information for ffca.caibi379[.]com indicate that the registrant email and address fields for the domain were updated on June 7, 2019.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The A record for the domain was updated on September 9, 2019 at which time it resolved to the IP 34.80.27[.]200 contained within an ASN owned by Google.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: For the prior eight months beginning on January 2, 2019 and encompassing the period of activity discussed by enSilo, the domain was hosted on several IP’s in an ASN owned by APNIC Hostmaster.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The shift away from IP infrastructure owned by APNIC represents a departure in threat actor infrastructure hosting tactics well after the publication by enSilo and within the weaponization period for TA410’s campaign targeting US utilities.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While this research is not conclusive, it demonstrates that all observed TA429 (APT10) similarities and indicators of compromise were available publicly prior to the start of TA410 campaigns.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Therefore, while not conclusive from current analysis, the possibility remains that these overlaps represent false flag activity by the TA410 threat actor.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Based on this analysis Proofpoint analysts track TA410 as a distinct threat actor from TA429 (APT10) at this time.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Conclusion
The convergence of LookBack and FlowCloud malware campaigns in November 2019 demonstrates the capabilities of TA410 actors to distinctly utilize multiple tools as part of a single ongoing campaign against US utilities providers.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Both malware families demonstrate a level of sophistication in their conception and development while the extensible code base of FlowCloud malware suggests that this group may have been operating as early as 2016.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: TA410 operators demonstrate a willingness to dynamically evolve phishing tactics to increase the effectiveness of their campaigns and a keen eye towards plausible social engineering within a very select targeted sector.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: It remains unclear if the nature of the tactics and indicators that are shared with TA429 (APT10) were developed by this group or culled from readily available technical reporting that pre-dated these campaigns.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The possibility remains that these overlaps represent intentional false flag efforts to cloak the identity of these perpetrators while they targeted a critical and geo-politically sensitive sector of energy providers in the US.
source: TA410_ Malware Attacks Against U.S. Utilities Sector _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Regardless of the actor’s intention, TA410 has established itself as a motivated actor with mature toolsets carrying out long term campaigns against highly important and geographically concentrated target sets.

RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT



RedLeaves
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Email




Hi again, this is Shusei Tomonaga from the Analysis Center.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Since around October 2016, JPCERT/CC has been confirming information leakage and other damages caused by malware ‘RedLeaves’.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: It is a new type of malware which has been observed since 2016 in attachments to targeted emails.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This entry introduces details of RedLeaves and results of our analysis including its relation to PlugX, and a tool which is used as the base of this malware.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
How RedLeaves runs
To have the RedLeaves injected into the process of Internet Explorer, the following steps will be taken (Figure1):
Figure 1: Flow of events until RedLeaves runs






Malware samples that JPCERT/CC has analysed create the following three files in %TEMP% folder and execute a legitimate application when executed.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
A legitimate application (EXE file): a signed, executable file which reads a DLL file located in the same folder
A Loader (DLL file): a malicious DLL file which is loaded by the legitimate application
Encoded RedLeaves (DATA file): Encoded data which is read by the loader

When the legitimate application is executed, it loads the loader located in the same folder through DLL Hijacking (DLL preloading).
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The loader, which is loaded in the legitimate application, reads and decodes the encoded RedLeaves and then executes it.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The executed RedLeaves launches a process (Internet Explorer) depending on its configuration, and injects itself there.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Then, RedLeaves starts running in the injected process.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following section explains the behaviour of the injected RedLeaves.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Behaviour of RedLeaves
RedLeaves communicates to specific sites by HTTP or its custom protocol and executes commands that are received.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 2 is the PE header of the injected RedLeaves.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Strings such as “MZ” and “PE” are replaced with “0xFF 0xFF”.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 2: Injected RedLeaves






The injected RedLeaves connects to command and control (C&C) servers by HTTP POST request or its custom protocol.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Destination hosts and communication methods are specified in its configuration.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Please refer to Appendix A for more information.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Below is an example of the HTTP POST request.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Table B-1 and B-2 in Appendix B describe the format of the data sent.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
POST /YJCk8Di/index.php
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept: */*
Content-Length: 140
Host: 67.205.132.17:443

[Data]
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The data is encrypted with RC4 (the key is stored in its configuration) and contains the following: 
__msgid=23.__serial=0.clientid=A58D72524B51AA4DBBB70431BD3DBBE9
The data received from the C&C servers contain commands.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Depending on the received commands, RedLeaves executes the following functions (Please see Table B-3 in Appendix B for the details of received data):

Operation on files
Execute arbitrary shell commands
Configure communication methods
Send drive information
Send system information
Upload/download files
Screen capture
Execute proxy function

Base of RedLeaves’s Code
JPCERT/CC analysed RedLeaves and confirmed that its code has a lot in common with the source code of Trochilus[1], a type of RAT (Remote Administration Tool), which is available on Github.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 3 shows part of the code to process received data.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
It is clear that it processes the same data as listed in Table B-3 in Appendix B.
Figure 3: Part of Trochilus’s source code
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: It is presumed that RedLeaves is built on top of Trochilus’s source code, rather than from scratch.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Relation to PlugX
Comparing RedLeaves samples that JPCERT/CC has observed with PlugX, used by certain attacker groups in the past, we identified that similar code is used in some processes.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Below are the sequence of instructions observed when the sample creates three files (a legitimate application, a loader and encoded RedLeaves or PlugX).
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 4: Comparison of file creation process






Furthermore, the process in which the loader decodes the encoded data (encoded RedLeaves or PlugX) is similar.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 5: Comparison of file decode process






JPCERT/CC has also confirmed that some of the RedLeaves and PlugX samples that share the above code also communicate with common hosts.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: From this observation, it is presumed that the attacker group using RedLeaves may have used PlugX before.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Summary
RedLeaves is a new type of malware being observed since 2016 in attachments to targeted emails.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Attacks using this malware may continue.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The hash values of the samples introduced here are listed in Appendix C. Some of the RedLeaves’ destination hosts that JPCERT/CC has confirmed are also listed in Appendix D. Please check your devices for any suspicious communication with such hosts.
source: RedLeaves - Malware Based on Open Source RAT - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
- Shusei Tomonaga
(Translated by Yukako Uchida)

Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading

May 9, 2017
25 min read
 

 









Share on:



Share on Twitter




Share on LinkedIn




Share on Facebook




Share on Reddit




Email this post



Copy Link

 



At the beginning of April, Carbon Black Threat Research began analyzing a malware variant commonly referred to as Red Leaves, which appears to have code reuse from the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: During the last month, this malware family has been referenced in several security blogs and government alerts.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Carbon Black is publicly providing this technical write up to assist customers, other organizations, and researchers continuing to investigate incidents related to this malware family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Along with this report, Carbon Black is providing product specific queries, rules and scripts aimed at assisting in the detection and analysis of this malware family in the Carbon Black User Exchange.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The overall process of how the malware’s components are created on an infected system and the different points where the suite of Carbon Black products could detect the different stages of the malware are outlined in that User Exchange post.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This malware family has been observed in the wild since at least June 2016.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware uses a technique called DLL side loading, which is common with the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: DLL sideloading works by using a legitimate or benign executable file to load a modified DLL.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This DLL is responsible for loading and executing an encoded or encrypted malicious data file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The ultimate payload for this sample is a shellcode loader, which injects the Red Leaves implant, via process hollowing, into a hard coded process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The metadata for the initial dropper file that was analyzed is listed in the information below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text:
File Name : tea_leaves_First-Stage
 File Size : 3,804,160 bytes
 MD5 : b3139b26a2dabb9b6e728884d8fa8b33
 SHA1 : de5672c7940e4fad3c8145ce9e8a5fcb1da0fcee
 SHA256 : 5262cb9791df50fafcb2fbd5f93226050b51efe400c2924eecba97b7ce437481
 Fuzzy : 98304:drzo0aM7e5O92nAv/tyE6peB1IY8CEueiSH0h292bNcx:pzo0S4yRY8tueiSUh1bCx
 Compiled Time : Wed Feb 22 02:41:17 2017 UTC
 PE Sections (5) :
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text:
Name Size MD5
  .text 1,264,128 181494d7465a4b5f1c6624b89826d147
  .rdata 291,328 b80b1b78172e51912b085932c3a0e106
  .data 2,032,128 059174f08ccd413e22acc50c91374730
  .rsrc 40,448 cae79604deb6e0793c6a3282a1b63104
  .reloc 175,104 9e12d15095cb458e072e0eae5c4c5095
 Magic : PE32 executable for MS Windows (GUI) Intel 80386 32-bit
Technical Details
The initial stage of the sample analyzed has little functionality outside of dropping or creating the malicious second stage files on the infected system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: PlugX has in the past been documented as being delivered via a self extracting (SFX) Rar executable, which acts as the first stage dropper.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the files have been created on disk, the dropper will execute the Obedience.exe file, starting the overall process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: A brief overview of the entire process is outlined in the below two figures and the accompanying table.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The main dropper/installer creates the three component files on the infected system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The dropper creates the entrenchment mechanism (a link file in a startup folder, which is detailed further later in the report) and executes Obedience.exe.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text:
Obedience imports the GetVersion function from Starburn.dll
The GetVersion function from StarBurn.dll loads the the handkerchief.dat file and decodes the file into shared memory space.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Starburn.dll calls CreateProcess and hands control over to the decoded handkerchief.dat file, which is shellcode with an embedded payload.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode will load several standard libraries and create an iexplore.exe process in suspended state.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode then writes the embedded payload into the memory space for the Iexplore.exe process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The suspended Iexplore.exe process is then resumed and the Red Leaves implant begins its process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text:
First Stage – Dropper
The first stage dropper will push several hard-coded values to a function, which is responsible for decoding the three embedded files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: These files comprise the second stage of the overall malware setup.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below displays these values being pushed (highlighted in red) as well as being labeled for clarity.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The pushed values in the above image (file offsets and sizes), are passed to a function responsible for decoding and writing the files to disk, along with the hard coded file names.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The embedded files are decoded by the function displayed in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The function will decode the first half of the file with one set of XOR keys (these instructions are highlighted in red), and the second half of the function with a different set of XOR keys (these instructions are highlighted in yellow).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The XOR key sets are derived from a 16 byte ASCII string immediately preceding the encoded data, in which every other byte is used to XOR each byte of encoded data.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first eight bytes are used for the first half of the file and the last 8 bytes for the second half of the file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: To clarify this process, the data in the table below represents one of the encoded embedded files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first 16 bytes (which are in bold) are the ASCII string, from which the key sets are derived.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first half of the file is decoded by XORing each byte of encoded data with each byte which is designated in red below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The second half is of the file is then decoded in the same manner using the each byte, in blue, from the second half of the overall string.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The same result can be obtained by XORing each byte of the 4 byte key and then using the result to XOR each byte of encoded data, which in this specific scenario is 0x1B and clearly visible from the null areas of an executable file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

The file labeled as embed_1 is a legitimate and validly signed executable (typically used in conjunction with different CD software applications), and in this sample will be created as the hard coded name obedience.exe (it should be noted that the file name could easily be changed in other variants).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The file labeled as embed_2 is a slightly modified file that will be named StarBurn.dll.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The final file labeled as embed_3 is an encoded file that when decoded and executed will inject the Red Leaves implant into the memory of a target process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: All of these files will be be created in the current user’s Temp folder (ex. C:Users[account]AppDataLocalTemp).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first stage dropper is also responsible for installing the persistence mechanism for the malware, as a shortcut named persuasion.lnk in the current user’s startup folder.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shortcut or link file will point to the target file obedience.exe and will execute that file when the user logs into the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

Second Stage
Obedience.exe
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the benign file obedience.exe has been executed it loads several libraries, one of which is StarBurn.dll.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The below image displays the Import table from Obedience showing where the malicious GetVersion function is imported.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll is side loaded, which is a fairly common tactic often associated with the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: StarBurn.dll
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the GetVersion function from StarBurn.dll is imported it will execute and look for the hard coded filename handkerchief.dat in the directory where StarBurn.dll is located.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below highlights these actions.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The handkerchief.dat file’s data is then read into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The pseudo-code in the image below highlights the the next steps in the process (variables were renamed for clarity).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll function will make the address space where the handkerchief.dat data was read into memory read, write and executable (which is highlighted in the first red box).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The function will then decode the data in the same manner in which the previous embedded files were decoded, where a 16 byte ASCII string is used to derive 2 XOR key sets, which are then used to decode the first and second half of the files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll function will then create a thread with the starting address of the decoded data, is highlighted in the second red box.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The decoded data is shellcode with an additional embedded payload.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The table below is a small excerpt of the decoded shellcode, which will load the Red Leaves implant into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

Shellcode Loader
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode will load several common libraries which will be used to inject the Red Leaves payload into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode decodes (using a single byte XOR of 0x53) a portion of the implant’s configuration block, where the processname is stored that will be injected into via process hollowing.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below shows the code responsible for configuration decoding, highlighted in red.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode loader will then create a process in suspended state, in this case the target process was Iexplore.exe.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below, which has been commented for clarity, displays where the shellcode creates the suspended thread.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The Red Leaves payload will then be written to that process’ memory location and the thread is then resumed allowing the Red Leaves implant to impersonate Internet Explorer and communicate with the pre-configure C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: As other research reports have pointed the embedded Red Leaves implant has the MZ and PE ASCII characters from the DOS and PE headers overwritten with the values 0xFF, which are highlighted in red in the table below.

Third Stage – Red Leaves Implant
Once the Red Leaves malware is running the program will initially decode its configuration block, which is encoded using a single byte XOR (in this example the 0x53).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This functionality is highlighted in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block is 0x940 bytes in length and contains several different options related to how the malware will install itself as well as where and how it will communicate with the hard coded C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block itself is a list of null terminated strings and binary values, which correspond to hard coded values.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block is detailed in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The Value section are the values present in the sample that was analyzed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The 4 value is used for TCP and HTTP.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: If this value is used it will iterate through the hard coded ports 443, 53, 80, and 995 for each C2 it can properly resolve.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text:
This area contains a null terminated string that is the key used in the RC4 algorithm that the malware employs to encrypt communications with the C2




After the configuration data has been decoded the malware will go into the main communication thread creation function, which is responsible for initiating the communications to the embedded C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The connection mode value is evaluated and the malware will used the appropriate functions to either use a custom protocol or standard APIs to communicate with the C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The value in this sample is 4 which will then attempt to resolve the different C2s iterating through the ports 443, 53, 80, and 995 (in that specific order).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once a connection has been established the malware will communicate with the C2 utilizing the RC4 algorithm with the key “Lucky123”.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware uses a series of command Identifiers, which are parsed, and then the program will pass control to the appropriate functions to carry out commands and return the responses or data back to the C2.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The jump table responsible for evaluating commands is displayed in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The communication protocol has been well documented in other research papers, which can be reviewed for further information.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware itself has the following capabilities, which allow the malware to be used as an efficient Remote Access Tool (RAT).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

Proxy Tunneling


Create ScreenShots


Bind to Sockets


Impersonate Users

Email




Since around October 2016, JPCERT/CC has been confirming emails that are sent to Japanese organisations with a ZIP file attachment containing executable files.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The targeted emails, which impersonate existing persons, are sent from free email address services available in Japan.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Also, the executable files’ icons are disguised as Word documents.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: When the recipient executes the file, the machine is infected with malware called ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This blog article will introduce characteristics of ChChes, including its communication.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
ZIP files attached to Targeted Emails
While some ZIP files attached to the targeted emails in this campaign contain executable files only, in some cases they also contain dummy Word documents.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Below is the example of the latter case.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 1: Example of an attached ZIP file






In the above example, two files with similar names are listed: a dummy Word document and an executable file whose icon is disguised as a Word document.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: By running this executable file, the machine will be infected with ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: JPCERT/CC has confirmed the executable files that have signatures of a specific code signing certificate.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The dummy Word document is harmless, and its contents are existing online articles related to the file name “Why Donald Trump won”.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The details of the code signing certificate is described in Appendix A.
Communication of ChChes
ChChes is a type of malware that communicates with specific sites using HTTP to receive commands and modules.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: There are only few functions that ChChes can execute by itself.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This means it expands its functions by receiving modules from C&C servers and loading them on the memory.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is an example of HTTP GET request that ChChes sends.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Sometimes, HEAD method is used instead of GET.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: GET /X4iBJjp/MtD1xyoJMQ.htm
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
HTTP/1.1
Cookie: uHa5=kXFGd3JqQHMfnMbi9mFZAJHCGja0ZLs%3D;KQ=yt%2Fe(omitted)
Accept: */*
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
User-Agent:
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
[user agent]
Host:
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
[host name]
Connection: Keep-Alive
Cache-Control: no-cache

As you can see, the path for HTTP request takes /[random string].htm, however, the value for the Cookie field is not random but encrypted strings corresponding to actual data used in the communication with C&C servers.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The value can be decrypted using the below Python script.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: data_list = cookie_data.split(';')
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: dec =
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
[]
for i in range(len(data_list)):
    tmp = data_list[i]
    pos = tmp.find("=")
    key = tmp[0:pos]
    val = tmp[pos:]
    md5 = hashlib.md5()
    md5.update(key)
    rc4key = md5.hexdigest()[8:24]
    rc4 = ARC4.new(rc4key)
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
dec.append(rc4.decrypt(val.decode("base64"))[len(key):])
print("[*] decoded: " + "".join(dec))
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is the flow of communication after the machine is infected.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 2: Flow of communication






The First Request
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The value in the Cookie field of the HTTP request that ChChes first sends (Request 1) contains encrypted data starting with ‘A’.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is an example of data sent.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 3: Example of the first data sent






As indicated in Figure 3, the data which is sent contains information including computer name.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The format of the encrypted data differs depending on ChChes’s version.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The details are specified in Appendix B.
As a response to Request 1, ChChes receives strings of an ID identifying the infected machine from C&C servers (Response 1).
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The ID is contained in the Set-Cookie field as shown below.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 4: Example response to the first request






Request for Modules and Commands
Next, ChChes sends an HTTP request to receive modules and commands (Request 2).
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: At this point, the following data starting with ‘B’ is encrypted and contained in the Cookie field.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
B[ID to identify the infected machine]

As a response to Request 2, encrypted modules and commands (Response 2) are sent from C&C servers.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following shows an example of received modules and commands after decryption.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 5: Decrypted data of modules and commands received






Commands are sent either together with modules as a single data (as above), or by itself.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Afterwards, execution results of the received command are sent to C&C servers, and it returns to the process to receive modules and commands.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This way, by repeatedly receiving commands from C&C servers, the infected machines will be controlled remotely.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: JPCERT/CC’s research has confirmed modules with the following functions, which are thought to be the bot function of ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Encrypt communication using AES
Execute shell commands
Upload files
Download files
Load and run DLLs
View tasks of bot commands
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Especially, it was confirmed that the module that encrypts the communication with AES is received in a relatively early stage after the infection.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: With this feature, communication with C&C servers after this point will be encrypted in AES on top of the existing encryption method.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Summary
ChChes is a relatively new kind of malware which has been seen since around October 2016.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As this may be continually used for targeted attacks, JPCERT/CC will keep an eye on ChChes and attack activities using the malware.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The hash values of the samples demonstrated here are described in Appendix C. The malware’s destination hosts that JPCERT/CC has confirmed are listed in Appendix D. We recommend that you check if your machines are communicating with such hosts.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Thanks for reading.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
- Yu Nakamura
(Translated by Yukako Uchida)

The code signing certificate attached to some samples are the following:

        Subject Public Key Info:
(Omitted)

The graph below shows the relation between the version numbers of the ChChes samples that JPCERT/CC has confirmed and the compile times obtained from their PE headers.
