text:
Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign | Symantec Enterprise Blogs














Symantec Enterprise BlogsThreat IntelligenceMenuMain menuBlogs HomeThreat Intelligence - All DivisionsFeature Stories - Symantec EnterpriseExpert Perspectives - Symantec EnterpriseSymantec and AIProduct InsightsRansomwareSolarWindsRSA Conference日本語SearchBroadcom HomeThreat Hunter TeamSymantecTwitterLinkedInSHAREPosted: 17 Nov, 20208 Min ReadThreat Intelligence Translation: 日本語 SubscribeFollowtwitterlinkedinJapan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack CampaignEvidence that advanced persistent threat group Cicada is behind attack campaign targeting companies in 17 regions and multiple sectors.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: A large-scale attack campaign is targeting multiple Japanese companies, including subsidiaries located in as many as 17 regions around the globe in a likely intelligence-gathering operation.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Companies in multiple sectors are targeted in this campaign, including those operating in the automotive, pharmaceutical, and engineering sector, as well as managed service providers (MSPs).
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The scale and sophistication of this attack campaign indicates that it is the work of a large and well-resourced group, with Symantec, a division of Broadcom (NASDAQ: AVGO), discovering enough evidence to attribute it to Cicada (aka APT10, Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper).
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Cicada has been involved in espionage-type operations since 2009, and U.S. government officials have linked the activities of APT10, which we track as Cicada, to the Chinese government.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Cicada has historically been known to target Japan-linked organizations, and has also targeted MSPs in the past.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The group is using living-off-the-land tools as well as custom malware in this attack campaign, including a custom malware - Backdoor.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Hartip - that Symantec has not seen being used by the group before.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Among the machines compromised during this attack campaign were domain controllers and file servers, and there was evidence of files being exfiltrated from some of the compromised machines.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The attackers extensively use DLL side-loading in this campaign, and were also seen leveraging the ZeroLogon vulnerability that was patched in August 2020.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: How was this campaign discovered?
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: This campaign was first discovered by Symantec when suspicious DLL side-loading activity on one of our customer’s networks triggered an alert in our Cloud Analytics technology, which is available in Symantec Endpoint Security Complete (SESC).
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: This activity was then reviewed by our Threat Hunter analysts before being passed on to our investigations team for further analysis.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Cloud Analytics leverages artificial intelligence in order to comb through Symantec’s vast data and spot patterns associated with targeted attacks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It is capable of automatically flagging incidents that would otherwise have taken thousands of hours of analyst time to identify.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The initial Cloud Analytics alert allowed our threat hunting team to identify further victims of this activity, build a more complete picture of this campaign, and attribute this activity to Cicada.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It also allowed us to update and create new protections to ensure our customers are protected from this activity.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Victims
This campaign has been ongoing since at least mid-October 2019, right up to the beginning of October 2020, with the attack group active on the networks of some of its victims for close to a year.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The campaign is very wide-ranging, with victims in a large number of regions worldwide.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Figure 1.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Locations of some of the companies targeted in this campaign; most of those targeted have links to Japan or Japanese organizationsThe companies hit are, in the main, large, well-known organizations, many of which have links to Japan or Japanese companies, which is one of the main factors tying the victims together.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Cicada has been known to have a strong focus on Japanese organizations in previous attack campaigns.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: As is clear from the map in Figure 1, South and East Asia are strong areas of focus for the attackers in this campaign.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It is unusual to see a reportedly Chinese-government-linked group attacking companies within China’s borders but, like many of the companies targeted in this campaign, the target in that instance is a subsidiary of a Japanese organization.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: We also saw similar loaders on all the victim networks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
These are among the main factors linking these victims together, with all of them coming from a wide variety of sectors, including:

Automotive, with some manufacturers and organizations involved in supplying parts to the motor industry also targeted, indicating that this is a sector of strong interest to the attackers
Clothing
Conglomerates
Electronics
Engineering
General Trading Company
Government
Industrial Products
Managed Service Providers
Manufacturing
Pharmaceutical
Professional Services

The amount of time the attackers spent on the networks of victims varied, with the attackers spending a significant amount of time on the networks of some victims, while spending just days on other victim networks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: In some cases, too, the attackers spent some time on a network but then the activity would cease, but start again some months later.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Tactics, tools, and procedures
We observed the attackers using a wide variety of living-off-the-land, dual-use, and publicly available tools and techniques in these attacks, including:

Network Reconnaissance – gathering information from machines on the network.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Credential Theft – stealing user names and passwords, potentially to provide them with further access to the victim network.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: RAR archiving – files are transferred to staging servers before exfiltration.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: They may be encrypted or compressed, to make them easier to extract.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Certutil – a command-line utility that can be exploited and used for various malicious purposes, such as to decode information, to download files, and to install browser root certificates.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Adfind – a command-line tool that can be used to perform Active Directory queries.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Csvde – can be used to extract Active Directory files and data.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Ntdsutil – can be used as a credential-dumping tool.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: WMIExec – can be used for lateral movement and to execute commands remotely.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: PowerShell - a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It can be used to find information and execute code, and is frequently abused by malicious actors.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The threat actors also use a legitimate cloud file-hosting service for exfiltration.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The attackers also use DLL side-loading at multiple stages during the attack, including using it to load Backdoor.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Hartip.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: DLL side-loading occurs when attackers are able to replace a legitimate library with a malicious one, allowing them to load malware into legitimate processes.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Attackers use DLL side-loading to try and hide their activity by making it look legitimate, and it also helps them avoid detection by security software.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It is a tactic that is commonly used by APT groups and has often been observed being used by nation-state backed actors.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Monitoring networks for unusual activity, as Symantec’s Cloud Analytics technology does, is key for detecting this kind of malicious activity.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The attackers were also seen deploying a tool capable of exploiting the ZeroLogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The critical elevation-of-privilege vulnerability was first disclosed and patched on August 11, 2020, and can allow attackers to spoof a domain controller account and then potentially use it to steal domain credentials, take over the domain, and completely compromise all Active Directory identity services.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: It has been exploited by multiple malicious actors since its disclosure, leading both Microsoft and the Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to issue warnings to Windows users to patch the issue as quickly as possible.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Links to Cicada
The scale and sophistication of this attack campaign indicate that it is the work of a large and well-resourced group, such as a nation-state actor, with Symantec discovering enough evidence to attribute it with medium confidence to Cicada.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Symantec analysts have linked this activity to Cicada due to the use of previously seen obfuscation techniques and shellcode on loader DLLs.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Activity seen in one of the victim organizations has various trait similarities with previously seen Cicada activity that was described in a blog by Cylance in 2019, including:

Third-stage DLL has an export named "FuckYouAnti"
Third-stage DLL uses CppHostCLR technique to inject and execute the .NET loader assembly
.NET Loader is obfuscated with ConfuserEx v1.0.0
Final payload is QuasarRAT – an open-source backdoor used by Cicada in the past

In another affected organization, the loaders deploying Backdoor.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Hartip overlap in the obfuscation and shellcode used, making us confident it is the same actor in both organizations.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Similarities between activity in both organizations
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Side-loading DLL
C++ usage
API call sequence
GetModuleFileName -> lstrcat -> CreateFile -> ReadFile
Load next-stage payload from another file
Obfuscation: lots of garbage OutputDebugString, _time64, srand, rand API calls

Figure 2.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Image showing links between Cicada and two victim organizations in this campaignThese similarities leave us confident that this is the same group carrying out this activity in both organizations, and that this group is Cicada.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Historically, Cicada has been seen using custom DLL loaders to decrypt and execute its final payload, as is observed in these attacks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: We also saw similar loaders as those used in these two organizations used on other victim networks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The scale of the operations also points to a group of Cicada’s size and capabilities.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The targeting of multiple large organizations in different geographies at the same time would require a lot of resources and skills that are generally only seen in nation-state backed groups.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The link all the victims have to Japan also points towards Cicada, which has been known to target Japanese organizations in the past.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The targeting of MSPs is also a hallmark of Cicada’s activity.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Successfully compromising an MSP can give attackers high-level access to multiple companies without them having to compromise the individual companies’ networks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: We have also seen Cicada utilizing some of the same publicly available tools – such as WMIExec – in the past.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The attackers also take various steps to reduce the chances of their activity being spotted – including searching for security software on victim machines using WMIC, and using PowerShell to clear event logs to hide their activity once they are finished on victim machines.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: This kind of activity is the hallmark of sophisticated and experienced threat actors.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: All of these facts point to Cicada being the perpetrator of these wide-ranging and sophisticated attacks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Intelligence gathering and stealing information has generally been the motivation behind Cicada’s attacks in the past, and that would appear to be the case in this attack campaign too.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: We observed the attackers archiving some folders of interest in these attacks, including in one organization folders relating to human resources (HR), audit and expense data, and meeting memos.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Conclusion
Japan-linked organizations need to be on alert as it is clear they are a key target of this sophisticated and well-resourced group, with the automotive industry seemingly a key target in this attack campaign.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: However, with the wide range of industries targeted by these attacks, Japanese organizations in all sectors need to be aware that they are at risk of this kind of activity.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Cicada clearly still has access to a lot of resources and skills to allow it to carry out a sophisticated and wide-ranging campaign like this, so the group remains highly dangerous.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Its use of a tool to exploit the recently disclosed ZeroLogon vulnerability and a custom backdoor that has not been observed by Symantec before show that it continues to evolve its tools and tactics to actively target its victims.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: The group’s use of techniques such as DLL side-loading and a wide array of living-off-the-land tools underline the need for organizations to have a comprehensive security solution in place to detect this kind of suspicious activity before actors like Cicada have the chance to deploy malware or steal information from their networks.
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text:
Protection/Mitigation
This activity was first discovered thanks to an alert triggered by our Cloud Analytics technology, which is available in Symantec Endpoint Security Complete (SESC).
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

text: Indicators of Compromise (IoCs)
source: Japan-Linked Organizations Targeted in Long-Running and Sophisticated Attack Campaign _ Symantec Enterprise Blogs.html

Malware
How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: We have seen an increase in attacks that leverage malicious LNK files that use legitimate apps—like PowerShell—to download malware or other malicious files.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
By: Benson Sy
		
			May 25, 2017
Read time: 5 min (1251 words)
	















Save to Folio






 Subscribe












Update as of May 30, 2017, 5:00 AM CDT to update the date referencing Trojan downloaders that used .zip files within .zip
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: files from "2016" to "2017".
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: PowerShell is a versatile command-line and shell scripting language from Microsoft that can integrate and interact with a wide array of technologies.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: It runs discreetly in the background, and can be used to obtain system information without an executable file.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: All told, it makes an attractive tool for threat actors.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: There were a few notable instances where cybercriminals abused PowerShell: in March 2016 with the PowerWare ransomware, and in a new Fareit malware variant in April 2016.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Because this seemed to be an upward trend, security administrators became more familiar with how to prevent PowerShell scripts from doing any damage.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: However, cybercriminals are staying ahead of the curve by using alternative means of executing PowerShell script—Windows LNK (LNK) extensions.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: LNK files are usually seen by users as shortcuts, and used in places like the Desktop and Start Menu.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: LNK was actually already used as an attack vector as early as 2013.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: And in early 2017, we noted how Trojan downloaders used a .zip within a .zip to disguise a LNK file attachment that led to the Locky ransomware.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Now, we’re seeing an increase in attacks that leverage malicious LNK files that use legitimate apps—like PowerShell—to download malware or other malicious files.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: To illustrate how the trend of using LNK files is rising, note how one single LNK malware (identified by Trend Micro as LNK_DLOADR.*) has had a significant jump in detections since January 2017.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
The steep rise shows how popular this method is becoming:

Figure 1.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Detected LNK_DLOADR over a 4 month period
Recent LNK-PowerShell and ChChes attacks
In October 2016 we saw attackers using the combination of LNK, PowerShell, and the BKDR_ChChes malware in targeted attacks against Japanese government agencies and academics.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
The attack used a fake .jpg extension to camouflage the malicious PowerShell file.

Figure 2.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Attack used to compromise Japanese targets in October 2016
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: In January 2017 we spotted the group APT10 (also called MenuPass, POTASSIUM, Stone Panda, Red Apollo, and CVNX) using a similar attack for a wide-spread spear phishing campaign.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: In this version, the LNK file executes CMD.exe, which in turn downloads a fake .jpg file hiding the malicious PowerShell script.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: The group has continued to evolve their cyberespionage activities, and in April 2017 they used a similar strategy to also download BKDR_ChChes, which is a popular malware used in targeted attacks.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
New LNK-PowerShell attacks
We identified one campaign, likely still ongoing, that has a new and complicated LNK strategy.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: These attackers seem to be using several layers of command line, built-in, Windows tools.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: They send a phishing email with lures that push the victim to “double click for content”, typically a DOCX or RTF file embedded with a malicious LNK.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Instead of directly executing PowerShell, the LNK file will execute MSHTA.exe (a file used for opening HTML applications), which executes a Javascript or VBScript code that in turn downloads and executes the PowerShell script.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
The PowerShell then executes a reverse shell (like Metasploit or Cobalt Strike) to complete the compromise.

Figure 3.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Complex LNK attack leveraging MSHTA.exe files
Last month we identified another spear phishing campaign also using a combination of LNK and PowerShell.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Unfortunately, the Command and Control (C&C) server where the main payload was stored is no longer accessible.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Their strategy seems to have fewer layers: the LNK file is embedded in a document file and if a user double clicks to open the message, it executes a PowerShell file (or a similar Windows command line tool) to download another script.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: The other script then downloads the main payload.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Figure 4.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
A less complicated LNK-PowerShell attack
We believe this specific attack may be politically motivated due to the economic and controversial subject of the decoy document.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: However, a full analysis is tricky because the trail ends when one of the C&C servers dies.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Without the full picture, it is difficult to associate this type of attack to known campaigns.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Hidden LNK commands
In many cases, these malicious LNK files can reveal valuable information about the attacker’s development environment.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: To help get this information, a quick analysis is possible by viewing the properties of the file.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: However, we are encountering cases where the command line argument is so long that it is no longer fully visible in the Properties > Shortcut window.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: When viewed, only the target application (CMD.exe, MSHTA.exe, and other non-malicious command line applications) is seen.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Figure 5.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Only the target application is visible
Our tests revealed that the maximum length for Shortcut > Properties > Target is only 260 characters.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Anything longer than that will not be visible.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: However, the maximum length for a command line argument is 4096 characters.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: The attacker actually pads several spaces or newline characters before the malicious argument.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Using a parser tool reveals that it is much longer (figure 6), though it still works normally:

Figure 6.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Padded file hiding malicious code
Attackers take advantage of this to try and disguise or hide the malicious portion of the code.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: This padding strategy may prevent a quick analysis of a LNK file, but any LNK parser can still extract the arguments without any problem.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Recommendations and best practices
Malware developers continue to upgrade their tools and look for different ways to deliver their malicious payloads.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Leveraging these LNK files is another strategy, but there are ways to prevent and mitigate these threats:

Upgrading PowerShell to version 5, which is available as part of the Windows Management Framework and included on Windows 10, is recommended.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Using Group Policy to turn on logging makes it easier to check for breaches.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Users and enterprises alike should be wary of executable files received through email.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
Most files ending in *.EXE are auto-rejected on an email server, but if security is a concern then administrators should consider adding *.LNK to the list
It is similarly not advisable to open any LNK file received via email (or from anywhere outside your machine).
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
To identify if it is a LNK file or not:

If inside an archive (e.g. WinRAR, WinZip), the LNK extension is clearly visible, as well as the “Type” (it says “Shortcut”).
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: For any Windows folder, you have to modify the registry if you want LNK files to be displayed.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: A small overlay arrow icon pointing to the upper right is one of the identifiers of a LNK file.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Another way to do this: switch the Windows folder to “Details View”, then check the “Type”.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: For LNK embedded in Word documents, users have to be aware of these types of attacks to know what to look for.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: The bottom line is: never open these kinds of documents without verifying the source.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: If your organization does not need any packager objects, then there is a way to disable the feature totally by editing the registry.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Trend Micro™ Smart Protection with Maximum XGen™ security infuses high-fidelity machine learning into a blend of threat protection techniques to eliminate security gaps across user activity and any endpoint—the broadest possible protection against advanced attacks.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ provides detection, in-depth analysis, and proactive response to today’s stealthy malware and targeted attacks in real-time.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text: It provides a comprehensive defense tailored to protect organizations against targeted attacks and advanced threats through specialized engines, custom sandboxing, and seamless correlation across the entire attack lifecycle, allowing it to detect threats, even without any engine or pattern update.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html

text:
December 10, 2020


Attack Activities by Quasar Family



Quasar









Email




Quasar
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: [1] is an open source RAT (Remote Administration Tool) with a variety of functions.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This is easy to use and therefore exploited by several APT actors.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: JPCERT/CC has confirmed that a group called APT10 used this tool in some targeted attacks against Japanese organisations.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As Quasar’s source code is publicly available, there are many variants of this RAT seen in the wild (referred to as “Quasar Family” hereafter).
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Some of them have been used in attacks against Japanese organisations, and they are seen as a threat as well as Quasar itself.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This article introduces the details of Quasar and Quasar Family.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Quasar overview
Quasar offers many functions which are intended for purposes such as device management, support operation and employee monitoring.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 1 describes Quasar’s functions and its supported environment as specified on GitHub.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 1: Quasar’s functions and supported environment
This tool was called “xRAT” at the time of its initial release, however, it was renamed as “Quasar” in August 2015.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The latest version is v1.4, released in June 2020.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 2: Quasar versions
As v1.3 and the earlier are still used in recent attacks, this article explains the functions of both v1.3 and v1.4.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Communication protocol
Quasar v1.3 uses its custom protocol which combines AES and QuickLZ.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In v1.4, however, Protocol Buffer (developed by Google) is used for data serialisation instead.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In addition, the entire communication is encrypted with TLS1.2.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 3 shows the comparison of the communication format in v1.3 and v1.4.
Figure 3: Quasar’s communication format
Communication flow
In v1.3, once a client connects to a server, authentication is performed.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: After that, the main body of data including the commands are exchanged.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: On the other hand, the authentication is replaced by a TLS handshake in v1.4, and the data exchange begins after that.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 4 illustrates Quasar’s communication flow between a client and a server.
Figure 4: Quasar’s communication flow
 
Configuration
Quasar possesses its configuration in itself.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: It is encrypted by the combination of AES and BASE64 encoding.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: It is decrypted with the value specified in “ENCRYPTIONKEY” in the configuration when executed.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 5: Quasar configuration
Figure 6: Configuration format
Table 1 details the configuration for Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:

Commands
In v1.3, command sets are defined for “typeof” calls.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

* “Clone” in the category refers to variants which uses the entire source code of Quasar with some functions added or modified.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: “Partially copied” refers to variants created as a new RAT using parts of the original source code.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 8 shows the comparison of commands embedded in XPCTRA and Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 8: Comparison of commands(Left: XPCTRA /
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Right: Quasar)
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In the comparison above, it is clear that commands in XPCTRA are mostly identical to those in Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 9 shows the comparison of the salt value in AsyncRAT and Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 9: Comparison of salt value(Above: AsyncRAT / Below: Quasar)
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The salt value in AsyncRAT is identical to that in Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As Quasar Family applies some parts of the source code of Quasar, its configuration and communication protocol are also identical.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In some cases, some functions are customised, and as a result, some new configuration and commands are added.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Attack campaigns using Quasar
Quasar has been used in many attack campaigns.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Table 3 lists the differences of Quasar used by each attack group.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Table 3: Example of Quasar used by attack group


Attack group
Quasar version
Customisation
Obfuscation

No

-

No

source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Yes
ConfuserEx v1.0.0



The original Quasar with the default configuration value was used in most cases.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 10 shows an example configuration of Quasar used by APT 33.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 10: Configuration of Quasar used by APT33
In most parts, the default values of the builder generating Quasar are used as is, except for STARTUPKEY.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This way, attacker groups use the default values as per the original to avoid leaving any distinctive evidence.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In some cases, attackers customise Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: For example, APT 10 updated some features and used it in some attacks.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following sections will cover the details of this custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Configuration
Quasar used by APT 10 (hereafter “custom Quasar”) has the following additional values in the configuration.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
DOWNLOAD_URL
PROXY

Figure 11 shows the comparison of configuration in the custom Quasar and the original Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 11: Comparison of configuration(Left: custom Quasar /
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Right: original Quasar)
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In “PROXY”, a proxy server URL can be configured.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This ensures that the custom Quasar is able to communicate with a C2 server even if the target’s environment uses proxy servers.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
While the original Quasar uses CBC mode when encrypting configuration with AES, the custom Quasar uses CFB mode.
Figure 12: Comparison of AES code(Left: custom
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Quasar /
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Right: original Quasar)
Added/deleted commands
There are some changes to the commands in the custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 13 shows the comparison of commands in the custom Quasar and the original Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 13: Comparison of commands(Left: custom Quasar /
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Right: original Quasar)
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In the custom Quasar, new commands DoPlugin and DoPluginResponse are added while some including keylogger are deleted.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: With DoPlugin, new functions can be added by loading additional plugin modules.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: These new modules can be deleted with DoPluginResponse.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This change enables Quasar to dynamically extend its functions with commands while maintaining Quasar itself as simple as it can be.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This suggests the attacker’s intention to avoid detection by anti-virus software.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Error log creation
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The custom Quasar has a function to create error logs.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The file path of the error logs is hardcoded in itself.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 14:
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Error log creation
Communication protocol
The encryption algorithms for communication with a C2 server also differs in the custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: While the original Quasar uses AES and QuickLZ, the custom Quasar also uses XOR encoding.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 15 shows the XOR encoding process added to the custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 15: XOR encoding process
For AES encryption, the custom Quasar uses CFB mode instead of CBC mode, as seen in the configuration.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The encryption methods are as follows:

Original Quasar: QuickLZ
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
+ AES (mode CBC)
Custom Quasar: QuickLZ
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: + AES (mode CFB)
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
+ XOR 

C2 server activities
JPCERT/CC investigated the activities of Quasar Family C2 servers based on the characteristics discussed above.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As of November 2020, 76 IP addresses running as C2 servers have been identified.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Figure 16 shows the distribution of Quasar Family C2 servers which were revealed in this investigation.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
Figure 16: C2 server distribution
Multiple C2 servers are still running in different countries, which indicates its activeness.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
In closing
Besides Quasar, other open source RATs are being used in ongoing attack cases [7].
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Attackers are taking advantage of these tools to make attribution difficult and reduce the cost for developing attack infrastructure.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: It is estimated that this attack trends may continue.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations


62,875
 people reacted

7
  8  min. read



Share 


















 







          By Jen Miller-Osborn and Josh Grunzweig 
February 16, 2017 at 11:00 AM
Category: Unit 42
Tags: MenuPass



 



 
This post is also available in: 
    日本語 (Japanese)In 2016, from September through November, an APT campaign known as “menuPass”  targeted Japanese academics working in several areas of science, along with Japanese pharmaceutical and a US-based subsidiary of a Japanese manufacturing organizations.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: In addition to using PlugX and Poison Ivy (PIVY), both known to be used by the group, they also used a new Trojan called “ChChes” by the Japan Computer Emergency Response Team Coordination Center (JPCERT).
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: In contrast to PlugX and PIVY, which are used by multiple campaigns, ChChes appears to be unique to this group.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: An analysis of the malware family can be found later in this blog.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Interestingly, the ChChes samples we observed were digitally signed using a certificate originally used by HackingTeam and later part of the data leaked when they were themselves hacked.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Wapack labs also observed a similar sample targeting Japan in November.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: It’s not clear why the attackers chose to use this certificate, as it was old, had been leaked online, and had already been revoked by the time they used it.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Digital certificates are typically used because they afford an air of legitimacy, which this one definitely does not.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The attackers spoofed several sender email addresses to send spear phishing emails, most notably public addresses associated with the Sasakawa Peace Foundation and The White House.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: All the spear phishes were socially engineered with subjects appropriate for the target and the apparent sender.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: One of the more interesting subject lines was used in the White House attack; “[UNCLASSIFIED] The impact of Trump’s victory to Japan,” sent two days after the election.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Most of the attacks against academics involved webmail addresses using names of academics but are not tied to those academics openly online.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: However, all the spear phish recipients used email addresses tied to them online.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Figure 1.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Recent menuPass activity and some ties to older infrastructure
The C2 infrastructure in these attacks is largely actor registered, with only a few Dynamic Domain Name System (DDNS) domains.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: menuPass typically makes use of a mix of DDNS and actor-registered domains in their attack campaigns.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: All of the related hashes and C2s are in appendix at the end of this blog.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Ties to menuPass
There is not much public information about the APT campaign called menuPass (also known as Stone Panda and APT10).
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: A paper from FireEye in 2013 on several campaigns using PIVY included menuPass as one of them.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: A later blog added some additional details.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The group name is derived from one of the passwords they use with PIVY in their attacks.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Believed to have started activity in 2009 and to originate from China, the group initially was known for targeting US and overseas defense contractors but broadened their targeting as time passed.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: They have targeted Japanese organizations since at least 2014.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The newer ChChes malware family uses an import hash (bb269704ba8647da97377440d403ae4d) shared with other tools used by menuPass, affording an initial link.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: However, the ties are most strongly proved through infrastructure analysis, which shows a number of links between the newer infrastructure used in these attacks and older infrastructure publicly associated with the group.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The three circled domains represent C2s publicly reported as tied to menuPass, linked to domains not previously publicly reported as associated.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: These are only a few of multiple overlaps analysts can find while researching menuPass infrastructure.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
The circled known domains are the first three below:

apple[.]cmdnetview[.]com
fbi[.]sexxxy[.]biz
cvnx[.]zyns[.]com
cia[.]toh[.]info
2014[.]zzux[.]com
iphone[.]vizvaz[.]com


Figure 2.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
menuPass infrastructure overlaps
Two of these domains can further be tied into the newer C2 infrastructure.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Again, these are only a few of the overlaps that can be uncovered by analyzing the infrastructure used by menuPass.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
The domains in the below figure are:

cia[.]toh[.]info
2014[.]zzux[.]com
wchildress[.]com
lion[.]wchildress[.]com
kawasaki[.]unhamj[.]com
sakai[.]unhamj[.]com
kawasaki[.]cloud-maste[.]com
fukuoka[.]cloud-maste[.]com
yahoo[.]incloud-go[.]com
msn[.]incloud-go[.]com
www[.]mseupdate[.]ourhobby[.]com
contractus[.]qpoe[.]com


Figure 3.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Ties between new and older infrastructure.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Additionally, the passwords in the PIVY samples also fit known passwords used by the group – three samples use “menuPass” and the other uses “keaidestone.”
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: With these data points, we assess with high confidence the recent attacks were conducted by the menuPass group.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Following is our analysis of the ChChes malware family.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Malware Analysis
For this analysis, Unit 42 looked at the following file:



MD5
c0c8dcc9dad39da8278bf8956e30a3fc


SHA1
009b639441ad5c1260f55afde2d5d21fc5b4f96c


SHA256
6605b27e95f5c3c8012e4a75d1861786fb749b9a712a5f4871adbad81addb59e


Compile Time
2016-11-24 01:31:37 UTC



 
This malware is provided with an icon that appears to be that of a Microsoft Word document, as we can see in the image below.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Figure 4.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Icon used for ChChes
Additionally, we discovered that the samples identified in attacks against Japanese organizations were digitally signed using the certificate originally used by the Italian-based company, HackingTeam.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Readers may recall that HackingTeam was compromised and subsequently had a large amount of internal data exposed in July 2015.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: This data included a wealth of code used by the organization, including certificates.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The certificate in question was fairly old, and expired on August 4th, 2012.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: On July 10th, 2015, the certificate was revoked.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Figure 5.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Digital signing of ChChes

Figure 6.  Certificate revocation
Multiple instances of malware have been discovered using this certificate since it was originally leaked in 2015.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: It is unclear why the actors decided to use this certificate that is tied to known malicious samples for their own samples.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: One possibility may be to make attribution more difficult for analysts researching these threats.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: When the malware is initially run, it will first decrypt an embedded stub of code within the malware prior to executing it.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: This stub has many characteristics seen in shellcode, and begins by creating a new Import Address Table (IAT).
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: This new IAT is then referenced throughout the remainder of the code when calling Windows APIs.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The following snippet of assembly shows the newly created IAT being referenced to call various functions, such as GetProcessHeap, RtlAllocateHeap, RtlReAllocateHeap, and InternetReadFile.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Figure 7.  Newly created IAT being used to call Windows API functions
After the IAT has been generated, the malware will determine the path of %TEMP% and set its current working directory to this value.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
ChChes proceeds to collect the following information about the victim:

Hostname
Process Identifier (PID)
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Current working directory (%TEMP%)
Window resolution
Microsoft Windows version

This information is aggregated into a string such as the following:
WBQTLJRH9553618*2564?3618468394?C:\\Users\\ADMINI~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp?1.4.1 (1024x768)*6.1.7601.17514
Note
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: that in the string above, the ‘3618468394’ and ‘1.4.1’ strings are hardcoded within the malware itself.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: These may indicate versions of the malware or campaign identifiers, however, this has not been confirmed.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: After this data has been aggregated, it is uploaded to a hardcoded command and control (C2) server via HTTP.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
The data is embedded within the ‘Cookie’ HTTP header, as seen below
Figure 8.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Initial HTTP beacon for ChChes
The URI used above is randomly generated for each HTTP request made by ChChes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The data embedded within the Cookie header is encrypted using a unique technique.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: For each key/value pair, separated by a ‘;’, the malware will first perform a MD5 hash of the key, and extract the middle 16 bytes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The value is base64-decoded after the string is unquoted.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Finally, the base64-decoded data is decrypted using RC4 with the previously obtained 16 bytes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: All of the data is concatenated to form the final, decrypted data.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
The following Python code shows an example of decoding the supplied Cookie field:

'AWBQTLJRH9553618*2564?3618468394?C:\\Users\\ADMINI~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp?1.4.1 (1024x768)*6.1.7601.17514'




12

Decrypted String:'AWBQTLJRH9553618*2564?3618468394?C:\\Users\\ADMINI~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp?1.4.1 (1024x768)*6.1.7601.17514'





The initial ‘A’ character witnessed in the output above instructs the remote server that this is an initial beacon, or the first expected request sent by ChChes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The C2 will respond with a ‘Set-Cookie’ header that contains the middle 16 bytes of the MD5 hash performed against the hostname and PID.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: Using the above example, the C2 would perform the MD5 against ‘WBQTLJRH9553618*2564’.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: jgrunzweig$
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: echo -n
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
WBQTLJRH9553618*2564 | md5
7fc27808b331106210b6364c326569fd 




12

jgrunzweig$ echo -n
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html
menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The resulting middle 16 characters is ‘b331106210b6364c’.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
The subsequent request made by ChChes looks like the following:

Figure 9.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Second network request made by ChChes
Decrypted, we see the following contents stored within the Cookie field:
Bb331106210b6364c
The first character of ‘B’ signifies that this is the second request, and the remaining data is the 16 bytes previously seen in the C2 response within the Set-Cookie header.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: At this stage, the C2 server is expected to return content in the following format:
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
[Middle MD5][Base64-Encoded Data][Middle MD5]
The ‘Middle MD5’ field contains the middle 16 bytes of the MD5 hash of the ‘b331106210b6364c’ string.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: This would result in a string of ‘500089dadf52ae0b’ in this particular example.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: The ‘Base64-Encoded Data’ field contains a fairly complex structure that will store a module that is to be loaded and subsequently run by ChChes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
A visualization of this network communication can be seen in the following figure:

Figure 10.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Network flow of ChChes
ChChes acts as an initial infiltration point on a victim machine.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: It has the ability to load additional code that in turn may accomplish any number of tasks.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: During analysis, no C2 servers were found to be active, and Unit 42 was unable to identify any modules being loaded by ChChes.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
However, the JPCERT also recently analyzed this family and was able to collect modules that give ChChes the following functions:

Encryption of communication by AES
Execute shell command
Uploading and downloading files
Loading and executing the DLL
Task list of bot command

However, the lack of persistence built into ChChes suggests that it by itself is not intended to run on a victim’s machine for long periods of time.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: In a successful intrusion, it may be only a first stage tool used by the attackers to orient where they landed in a network, and other malware will be deployed as a second stage layering for persistence and additional access as the attackers move laterally through a network.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text:
Conclusion
These attacks show Japan continues to be a target of interest to APT campaigns.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: menuPass has targeted individuals and organizations in Japan since at least 2014, and as the same organizations and academics were largely targeted each month in these attacks, it further shows menuPass is persistent in attempts to compromise their targets.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: menuPass also heavily favors spear phishing, and so takes steps to socially engineer their spear phishes for maximum appearance of legitimacy.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: This, and their persistence, highlights the need for training and awareness of spear phishing on the part of both individuals and organizations likely to be targeted.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

text: menuPass is an ongoing APT campaign with a broad range of targets and will likely continue to target Japan in the future.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html

Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from these malware families and C2 infrastructure by:

All C2 domains are flagged as malicious in Threat Prevention and PAN-DB
All three families are properly tagged malware by WildFire.
source: menuPass Returns with New Malware and New Attacks Against Japanese Academics and Organizations.html
