ChessMaster Makes its Move: A Look into its Arsenal
ChessMaster, a campaign targeting Japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, managed service providers, and government agencies, employs malware-laden spear-phishing emails with decoy documents purporting to be legitimate.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
By: Benson Sy, Kawabata Kohei
		
			July 27, 2017
Read time: 4 min (1144 words)
	















Save to Folio






 Subscribe












From gathering intelligence, using the right social engineering lures, and exploiting vulnerabilities to laterally moving within the network, targeted attacks have multifarious tools at their disposal.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: And like in a game of chess, they are the set pieces that make up their modus operandi.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Take for instance the self-named ChessMaster, a campaign targeting Japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, managed service providers, and government agencies.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: It employs various poisoned pawns in the form of malware-laden spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: And beyond ChessMaster’s endgame and pawns, we also found red flags that allude to its links to APT 10, also known as menuPass, POTASSIUM, Stone Panda, Red Apollo, and CVNX.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: ChessMaster’s name is from pieces of chess/checkers/draughts we found in the resource section of the main backdoor they use against their targets: ChChes, which Trend Micro detects as BKDR_CHCHES.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
What makes the campaign unique is its arsenal of tools and techniques:

Malicious shortcut (LNK) files and PowerShell.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The LNK files execute Command Prompt that downloads a PowerShell script, which would either directly drop or reflectively load ChChes into the machine.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The latter method makes ChChes a fileless malware.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Self-extracting archive (SFX).
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: An archive that drops an executable (EXE), a dynamic-link library (DLL), and a binary file (.BIN).
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Upon their extraction, malicious code is injected into the process of a legitimate file/application (DLL hijacking).
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: ChessMaster takes it up a notch via load-time dynamic linking to trigger the malicious DLL’s function.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Runtime packers.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Throughout its campaign, ChChes used three packers to obfuscate itself and avoid detection.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The first had no encryption and a varied loader code.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The second had a buggy (or anti-emulation) exclusive OR (XOR) encryption technique.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The third added an AES algorithm on top of XOR encryption.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Their compile dates overlap, which indicates ChChes’ authors take cues and fine-tune their malware.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Second-stage payloads.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Additional malware are introduced to the infected system for persistence.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: These are actually variants of ChChes that use similar entry points but different and encrypted C&C communication.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Hacking Tools.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: ChessMaster draws on legitimate email and browser password recovery and dumping tools they’ve misused and modified for their campaign.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: These can restore forgotten passwords, which are then dumped and retrieved.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Lateral movement and further attacks can be worked out from here.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: TinyX.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: A version of PlugX sans the plug-in functionality that allows it to adopt new capabilities.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
TinyX is bundled separately in spear-phishing emails.
RedLeaves.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: A second-stage backdoor that operates like the open-source and fileless remote access Trojan (RAT) Trochilus, which is known for enabling lateral movement in the infected systems.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: RedLeaves adopted capabilities from PlugX. In April, a RedLeaves variant named himawari (Japanese for sunflower) emerged capable of evading YARA rules released during that time.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
ChessMaster and APT 10 Plays the Same Cyberespionage Game
APT 10/menuPass is a cyberespionage group whose specific campaign, Operation Cloud Hopper, attacked the intermediaries of their targets of interest—managed service providers (MSPs).
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Its notoriety stems from their prolific use of multifarious information-stealing backdoors and vulnerability exploits, along with the tenacity of its subterfuges, from spear-phishing emails to attack and infection chains.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: It also abused legitimate or open-source remote administration tools to steal data.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: If that sounded familiar, it's because ChessMaster and APT 10 appear to be playing the same cyberespionage game.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
Here’s a further illustration:
Figure 1: Similarities in ChessMaster and APT 10’s attack chain
We first saw ChChes set its sights on an organization that’s long been a target of APT 10/menuPass.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: As we caught and delved into more ChChes samples in the wild, however, we also saw how they followed the same pattern—exclusive packers, mutual targets, overlapping C&C infrastructure.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: ChChes’ packer, for instance, resembled the one used in menuPass’ old PlugX samples.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: DNS records also showed that some of their command and control (C&C) servers and domains resolved to the same IP address, or resided in the same subnet.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Are they operated by the same actors?
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Their commonalities make it appear so.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: It’s also known to happen; BlackTech’s cyberespionage campaigns are a case in point.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
Figure 2: Comparison of Emdivi and ChChes
ChessMaster’s ChChes also resembles another backdoor, Emdivi, which first made waves in 2014.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: They have the same endgame.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Both are second-stage payloads that use the system’s Security Identifier (SID) as encryption key so they execute only in their target’s machine.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Their difference lies in complexity—ChChes hides part of the decryption key and payload in registry keys to make it harder to reverse engineer.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: But that’s just one dot in several we’ve connected.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: In one instance, we detected PlugX and Emdivi on the same machine.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: This PlugX variant connected to an APT 10/menuPass-owned domain, but the packer is similar to that used by ChChes.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: While it’s possible it was hit by two different campaigns, further analysis told a different story.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Both were compiled on the same date, only several hours apart.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: We detected and acquired the samples the next day, which means both backdoors were delivered to the victim a day after they were compiled.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
Figure 3: Overview of the overlaps in ChessMaster and APT 10’s campaigns
Take ‘Control of the Center’
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Ultimately attacks like ChessMaster’s make pawns out of the systems, networks, devices and their users, all of which hold the organization’s crown jewels.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: This is why enterprises need to be steps ahead of the game: prepare, respond, restore, and learn.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Plan ahead—what techniques will attackers use?
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: How can I defend against them?
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Don’t just pull the plug—understand what happened to better assess and mitigate the damage.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text:
Fine-tune your response—what worked, what didn’t, and what could’ve been done better?
Defense in depth plays a crucial role especially for the IT/system administrators and information security professionals that watch over them.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The network, endpoints, servers, mobile devices, and web/email gateways are the bishops, knights, and rooks that underpin the enterprise’s crown jewels, which is why securing them is important.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Reduce their attack surface.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Keep the systems updated and regularly patched, and enforce the principle of least privilege.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Employ behavior monitoring and application control.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Deploy firewalls as well intrusion detection and prevention systems.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Implement URL categorization, network segmentation, and data categorization.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: ChessMaster’s gambit is spear-phishing, so it’s especially important to filter and safeguard the email gateway.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Additionally, foster a cybersecurity-aware workforce.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Seemingly benign icons or decoy documents can still swindle the victim, for instance.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: More importantly, develop proactive incident response and remediation strategies—threat intelligence helps enterprises prepare and mitigate attacks.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Like in chess, the more you understand your enemy’s moves, the more successful you can be at thwarting them.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: The Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) related to ChessMaster's campaigns is in this appendix.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: This has been presented in the RSA Conference 2017 Asia Pacific & Japan as “ChessMaster: A New Campaign Targeting Japan Using the New ChChes Backdoor” on July 27, 2017, in Marina Bay Sands, Singapore.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html

text: Updated on August 14, 2017, 11:50 PM to include IoCs related to ChessMaster.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
